elements.text: PART ONE
Opening Doctor Who theme tune, arranged by David Arnold.
Street sounds, old car horns.

... We present a talk by Professor John Morritz of the University of Minnesota entitled, The New Deal, Where Next. Later, it's a month now since the celebrated meteor lit up our skies. What was it? Where did it go?
Sudden crashing of glass. Taking things from a store.
Would you get moving, you great lunk?
Hey, hey! You can't hurry genius, my friend. Know what The Phantom says? There's a fine art to successful chicanery.
Ah, you don't even know what that means. Besides Ellis, we're breaking into a dime store. This ain't no bank heist. And we shouldn't even be doing this.
I've told you, Mousey, it's just insurance.
Jeez, if the boss knew we had some of the merchandise...
Yeah well, he ain't gonna know. Not until it's too late anyways.
Car horns continue in the background.
TARDIS materialisation. Control room hum.
Well, it's the historical repercussions, you see. The beat of one bat's wing eventually leads to a tropical storm. That sort of thing. Or was it a butterfly?
And that's what happened with ... what's his name...
Canute. He got a bit above himself, declared himself so powerful, he could turn back the tide.
Oh yes, I remember reading that somewhere. Listen, we are still heading for Singapore, aren't we?
Of course. Now, history records the King getting soggy ankles, but not until I'd intervened. Someone had been meddling.
Who?

One TARDIS, one twenty-fourth century Pulfidian Flood Controller, and an amoral Time Lord later, King Canute really did turn back the tide. And our friend had an unshakeable power base in Anglo Saxon Britain. Mucking about with Time is a risky business. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
Outside.
What's the time?
Er ... eleven thirty. Ellis?
He should be here.
Person appearing.
I'm here.
Jeez!
You got it?
Yeah. I got it.
Let me see.
Uh-uh. There are two sides to every bargain, old pal of mine. Say...
I'm only asking to see what I'm paying for.
Why don't you step out here into the light, Mister, and we can have a good look at you.
I don't think so.
Ellis, who is this wise guy?
Out here where I can see you. Or nobody gets nothin’.
Very well.
Walking forward.
Hey!
Oh God...
Let's shed a little light on those pretty mugs of yours. Well, well. Mr Mouse and Mr Ellis. Nice to renew our acquaintance.
Halliday, we was just...
Shut up.
I'm just trying to explain to Mr Halliday, Ellis, that...
I said shut up. What the hell are you doin’ here, Halliday?
Not ... quite what you were expecting, eh Ellis? Hands against the wall.
Oh, do as he says.
Ellis?
When are you...?
Noise of weapon being powered up.
Oh no, Ellis. Put that thing away.
Do I have to get nasty, Mr Ellis? Come out here where I can see you and get your damned hands up against that wall.
Ellis, for Christ sakes!
You wanna play hardball, wise guy, huh? This pistol belonged to my Dad. He never missed.
Gun cocked.
And neither do I.
Yeah? Yeah? And this ain't no Hallowe'en pop gun.
Electronic laser gun firing sound, sizzling, cry by HALLIDAY.
Oh, Jesus, Ellis.
ELLIS laugh.
Move.
Running. Car street sounds. TARDIS materialisation sound. Door opening.
Which is where you came in.
In the nick of time, or thereabouts.
Door closed. Walking out.
Put things back in their proper place. The King had to go through it all again, and this time...
...The tide came in. (Laughs.) What a silly...
Canute? I'll say. Charley!
Car horn as car zooms past.
You lousy jaywalking citizen!
Singapore, Nineteen Thirty?
Perhaps, let me see. Thirty Fourth Street and Broadway. Ah.
Not Singapore.
Well, judging by that skyline and that taxi-driver's language...
And that ... dead man.
And that dead man ... Oh. I'd have to say New York City.

Ladies and gentlemen, I have a grave announcement to make. Incredible as it may seem, both the observations of science and the evidence of our eyes lead to the inescapable assumption that those strange beings who landed in the Jersey Farmlands tonight, are the vanguard of an invading army from the planet Mars.
ORSON WELLES sighs.
Huh?
Who wrote this crap? I certainly didn't write this crap.
You will, Orson, you will.
The vanguard of an invading army - hogwash. We'd be better off pulling the whole thing, Jack.
What would you prefer, dear boy - Lorna Doone?
Well, why not? I can think of nothing more suitable for Hallowe'en except perhaps for - Little Lord Fauntleroy, now there's a thought.
Really Orson, now is not the time. Let's just get Howard's little play over and done and then we can concentrate on the important stuff.
Danton's death.
As you say, dear boy.
Mm.
Anyway, I like the news report idea, I think it's rather neat.
That's because you thought of it. Who'll be listening to us in any case? That damn ventriloquist is on.
I know.
Why do we bother?

Because Campbell's Soup pay us to. Now, you must think of yourself like Mr Bergen's little wooden friend, and get back in your box, Orson. I'm not letting you out of this studio until rehearsals are over.
Sigh. Clearing of throat.

This is Orson Welles, ladies and gentlemen, out of character to assure you that The War of the Worlds has no further significance than as the holiday offering it was intended to be. The Mercury Theatre's own radio version of dressing up in a sheet and...
(speaker) ... jumping out of a bush and saying "boo".
Sighing from BIX BIRO.
God...
Walking forwards.
(speaker) Starting now we couldn't soap all your windows and steal all your garden gates...
What? Is that you?
What are you trying to do?
Heavens, I'm sorry, Mr Biro, I saw the light, I figured someone must have forgot to lock the studio up.
Yeah - No, no - no, Carla. I'm just fixing some equipment, for Mr Welles.
Just like the old times, eh sir?
(laugh) Yeah, yeah, yeah.
They still in there, sir? Them and the Martians? (laugh.)
What? Oh. Oh, yeah.
(laugh) I don't know what they make all the fuss about. I mean, I see little green men all the time. All it takes is just a few hours with my old friend Jack Daniels. Not that I would, I wouldn't...
That's okay, Carla. I'll see you in the morning.
Walking off.
Yeah, goodnight, Mr Biro, sorry. Sorry I startled you.
BIX BIRO starts working on something
Come on, come on!
Bleeps - electronic.
Street scene.
Anything?
Erm ... a wallet, a gun, some loose change, keys...
Can I see the wallet? Hmm, JC Halliday, some sort of private detective.
THE DOCTOR gentle laugh.
What is it?
I believe it's usual in these circumstances to find a clue written on the back of a book of matches.
Mm ... Mm, what, like this book of matches?
Well done. What's in it?
Matches.
Uh, that's the trouble with clich@s.
Shall we tell the police or something, Doctor?
Probably not. I always seem to end up helping them with their enquiries. Perhaps it'd be better to go by Mr Halliday's office, and...
(alerted) Doctor?
Yes?
Oh, nothing. I thought I saw someone. Over there by that shop.
Mm, no-one there now. How's your stomach?
Pardon?
Look at his body.
Oh! Burnt?
Frazzled, more like.
Music playing.
And then the boss looks at the fat guy and he says, "How'd you get like that, Herman? You used to be such a skinny thing,” and the guy says, "Time is cruel, Don."
And what did you say, boss?
"Ice cream is crueller."
Laughter.
"Ice cream is crueller." Jeez, that was funny, boss. ‘Cause, you know, it was the ice
cream that must've made him fat, that - that's what the boss was sayin’...
Yeah, I think the boys are capable of understanding that, Ellis.
Er - yeah, boss, sure, boss, er ... Hey, do you want some more meatballs?
No.
Mind if I, er...?
Go ahead.
Plate movement.
Say, where'd you get to before, Ellis?
Oh ... just some business, boss.
Yeah. Ain't someone missin’?
Er ... yeah. Yeah, that little guy...
Mouse.
Yeah.
When I say I'm taking the boys out for dinner, I expect a full turnout, Ellis. You make sure of that.
Door swings open. Gasps by diners. Walking over.
Can I help you, gentlemen?
1: I guess so, Chaney. We've, er ... we've got a surprise for yous.
A surprise? I like surprises.
2: Yeah. Yous got a secret benefactor. He says, "Hey guys, give this to The Phantom."
What did you call me?
1: "I says, I don't know who you mean, sir." He says, "Well, go along to Luigi's on Thirty-Fourth and Lexington, and look for the guy with his nose shot off."
Why, you...
2: And then he says...
Guns cocked.
2: "... Shoot off the rest of his face for me, will you?"
Laughter by GANGSTER 2/GANGSTER 1.
I wouldn't do that if I were you, boys.
1: Oh no?
Gun powered up.
2: Oh crap.
Laser gun fired. Cries by GANGSTER 1/GANGSTER 2. Sizzling.
Luigi? Could we have the tab, please?
Si, Signor Chaney.
Walking in street.
So, it's not far off my time, Nineteen Thirty-Eight. I could get a boat home.
You know, it's a constant puzzle to me why so many of my travelling companions can't wait to leave me. I show them all the wonders of the Universe, and what thanks do I get. Ah!
Halliday's office.
Mm, at least according to his wallet, yes. Look - JC Halliday, Private Investigator, discretion assured.
What now?
Well, people are rarely killed without a reason, Charley, even in New York. Besides, there's the way he died. Concentrated radiation burst.
Is that what it was?
Indubitably.
Onwards and upwards, then.
Hmm?
After you.
Brisk walking.
Mr Halliday?
Pardon? Oh, erm - erm, yes, yes, that's me.
Doctor!
Doctor?
Doctor ... er, Jack Halliday, private investigator.
Indiscretion assured.
I never advertise the title. People badger you to look at their tonsils. Can I help?
With my tonsils?
No, I imagine you want to hire me.
You came recommended. Shall we go up?
Why not?
Clicking, twice of trying a lock.
Er - Charley, do you have, er ... my keys?
What? Oh, er, yes.
Trying a lock to open it.
My associate Miss Pollard. You are...?
My name is Glory Bee. I need your help, Mr Halliday, desperately.
I see. Well, erm, go on up, Miss Bee. It - it's the, er, the second floor.
Walking back.
Doctor, what do you think you're doing?
You know, I'm not at all sure. Let's see what happens, eh?
A crowded place.
No. As far as I'm concerned it's just a feeble attempt to recapture her youth.
Really?
Yeah.
I'm always trying to recapture my youth, but he keeps escaping.
Oh, Cosmo! (Laughs.) Oh, you are a card.
Queen of Hearts.
Tapping of glass.
(amplified) Distinguished guests, ladies and gentlemen. The founder of our feast.
I think you're wanted, Cosmo.
Uh-huh - in forty-nine states.
(amplified) Mr Cosmo Devine.
Applause.
Oh well, here goes.
Applause. Tapping microphone.
(amplified) Good evening, friends. And how delightful it is to see you all here. You know, as I was saying to the President the other day.
Laughter.

(amplified) "Why, President," I said. "What do you think of the new outfit?" Oh, I forgot to mention I dropped by the White House in this gorgeous lilac suit I had a little man run up for me. Later on he ran down it again, but ...
Laughter.

(amplified) I said, "Franklin, what do you think?" Well, he looked me up and down kind of sneery, I have to say and murmurs, "You forgot the pearls, Cosmo." I said "Pearls? With lilac? Are you insane?"
Laughter, applause.
(amplified) Well, I hope you've all got your cheque books ready. My theatre project is the most deserving cause I know.
Some laughter.
And I want to hear those cash registers ringing tonight. Oh, and don't forget - we have a special guest arriving later. None other than America's favourite Renaissance man himself, Mr Orson Welles.
Cheering, applause.
Professor Pearson. Could this occurrence possibly have something to do with the disturbances observed on the planet Mars?

Hardly, Mr Philips. This is probably a meteorite of unusual size and it's arrival at this particular time is merely a coincidence. However we shall conduct a search as soon as daylight permits. Blah, blah, blah...
ORSON WELLES yawns.
Shall we call it a day?
Oh yes please, let's call it a day.
All right everyone, rehearsal over. You all have your call times, I trust?
Standing to leave. Muttered replies. Keys fumbled, drop.
Coulouris, what are you doing with those keys? See you tomorrow.
Watch out for the Martians.
Laughter from the people leaving.
I'm sure there was one driving my cab last night. He could have been Czech, though, it's so difficult to tell them apart.
Well, considering what's brewing back home I bet he'd take alien invasion over Mr Hitler any day. Do you want a drink?
Naturally.
Oh - dammit, we're late for Cosmo Devine's little party.
Oh, to hell with that, I've got a table booked at the Excelsior.
Door opening.
Good evening Mr Houseman, Mr Welles.
Hello, Bix. To what do we owe this honour?
Honour?
Well, we don't get the chairman of the network visiting our little studios
every day, do we Jack?
Sadly no. Nice to see you, Mr Biro.
Yeah, yeah, yeah. Whatever masterpiece has the Mercury Theatre of the Air to give us next?
War Of The Worlds, sir. A Hallowe'en treat.
Or a Hallowe'en trick - depends on how you look at it.
The War Of The Worlds?
You don't know it? It's Wells.
(laugh) You wrote it?
Alas I cannot claim the honour, sir. Herbert George Wells, Mr Biro, of the noted scientific romances. You may have heard of him?
Yeah well, let's hope the public have, Mr Orson Welles, or the Columbia Broadcasting Service may have to think twice about renewing your contract. Good night to you.
Door closed.
Philistine! Why we had to get ourselves in hock with a ... mob stooge like Biro...
He has a point, my boy. We have to get ourselves noticed, and soon.
Crowded place.
Oh, a hell of a speech, Cosmo. Oh! My Lord, you should stand for Congress, sweetie.
Thank you, no, Mrs van Buren. I get all the scandal and vice I need in the theatre.
(laughs.) Oh, Cosmo!
If you will excuse me, I have a call to make.
Door opened.
Sit down, Miss Bee.
Door closed.
Charley, get the lady a chair.
Thank you. I prefer to stand.
Well, you don't mind if I...?
Sitting down.
That's a dead man's desk you've got your feet on, Doctor.
So Miss Bee, what's the rumpus? You cracking foxy with me or is you in trouble with the Bricks? They gonna drag you down to the hole because some guy gets shot through the pump with a heater?
Are you all right?
Local patter, Charley, it always helps break the ice. As it happens, it's a particular skill of mine.
Miss Pollard, is Mr Halliday unwell?
No, no, erm ... he just gets like that sometimes. I believe he was trying to say, how can we help you?
Clock ticking.
Come on, you son of a...
Telephone rings.

Hello? Yeah, yeah ... yeah, yes. I think I have the information you require. I'll transmit the signal as arranged ... Mm? Yeah, yeah, tomorrow. Yes. (Louder) Look, I know what I'm doing, dammit! (Calmer) I'm sorry, I'm sorry, look - Look, can I just speak to him, please? ... I done everything you asked. Please, just let him go!
Disconnection.
Hello?
Urgent tapping.
Hello? Look, let him go will you? Please!
Receiver slammed down.
God!
BIX BIRO sobs.
Echoed room as though underground.

Your boyfriend is certainly very worried about you, Mr Winkler. I must say, I'd be very flattered to find anyone so concerned for my welfare. Sadly this is not likely. It's oh-so-difficult to form close personal relationships in my line of work.
Gasp by WINKLER.
However, if Mr Biro does as he is told, there should be no reason for any ... unpleasantness.
Gasp by WINKLER. COSMO DEVINE chuckles.
You can go back to your little job at the CBS and everything will be hunky-dory. Let's hope for your sake that Mr Biro plays ball.
COSMO DEVINE chuckles.
It's my Uncle, Mr Halliday. He was here in the city for some kind of conference. We'd arranged to meet, but he didn't show.
Did you check his hotel?
First place I went. They had no record of him.
Are you sure it was the right one?
Perfectly - you see, I'd seen him there the afternoon before.
In his room?
No, the lobby.
What did you do next?
I went to the address he'd given for the conference.
Same result?
It was just a warehouse down by the East River.
Doctor, can I have a word?
Er, just one moment, Miss Bee.
Walking off.
What's the rumpus - I mean, what is it?
Should we be doing this? This poor woman's problem is nothing to do with us. She came here to find Halliday so he could find her Uncle.
Halliday's dead.
Exactly. And you're not going to be of much use to Miss Glory Bee by
indulging your private detective fantasies.
THE DOCTOR sighs.
No, I suppose you're right. Better refer to the police, or ... Miss Bee, this conference your Uncle was attending - what did you say it was?
Heavy water, or something. I really don't understand what his research is.
He's a scientist?
Didn't I say?
No. Heavy water? What's his field?
Oh, I don't know. Something about atoms or some such...
Atoms?
Yeah.
Doctor, why are you looking like that?
Remember how Halliday died, Charley?
Radiation burst, you said.
Hmm, I think Miss Bee's little problem may be more important than we thought.
Fizzing sounds.
Ellis, open the chute.
Throaty growl of alien from below.
Oh Jesus, boss. Would you look at that thing. I never seen the likes, It's...
It's a Golden Goose, Ellis, that's what it is.
Noise of something being slid over to them.
And look at the pretty little eggs it keeps layin’.
Yeah. (Laughs.)
Gun powered up.
And don't point that thing at me!
Gun powered down.
Where the hell is that little rat anyway?
Er, the ... the boys is bringing him in right now.
Door opened.
Ah.
Mr Chaney ... Mr Chaney sir, there's been a misunderstanding. I...
Shut up. Shut up, you lousy fake.
Thump, gasp.
Now, where's your partner?
I don't know what you mean, sir.
Thump, gasp by MOUSE.
I know someone's been fleecing me. I Know you're part of the scam, but I don't know who's behind it. Now, talk.
I swear I don't know, Mr Chaney. I was told to bring some of the merchandise to the store. It all went crazy. And then ... then your guys found me.
What the hell were you up to?
Oh - you can vouch for me, ca... can't you, Mr Ellis?
Shut your mouth! He ... he's crazy, boss.
Punch. MOUSE gasps.
I just borrowed the merchandise.
What, this merchandise?
Weapon powered up.
Not that one, sir, but it was like it.
How does it work, Ellis? Do you know? I mean ... I mean, if I pointed it at Mr Mouse here...
No ... No!
Yeah, you're right, you're right, I ain't through.
Weapon powered down.
So, your mysterious friend. He'd arranged to meet somebody?
Yeah, that's right.
He - he - he was gonna sell the boss's merchandise?
I - I guess so. I - I didn't know a thing. I - I swear it.
Okay, okay. But the guy who turned up - that wasn't who your friend expected, am I right?
Nah. It was Halliday. The private dick? We've had some run-ins with him before, when he was on the force. But somebody gave him what he wanted. Fried him. It w... it wasn't me, Mr Chaney...
That's okay, son. What do we care if an ex-cop gets his guts fried, huh? Huh?
DON CHANEY laughs, then ELLIS. MOUSE joins in, laughing nervously.
And you have no idea who this benefactor of yours is?
No, sir. I would tell you if I knew, I swear I would.
I believe you, kid. Yeah, it's a damn shame.
S-sir?
Well - if I thought you'd be any use to us, I'd keep you alive.
What? Oh - no - no, Mr Chaney, sir - I can help. I'll tell ya...
Shut up!
Punch. MOUSE cry.
You handled some of the merchandise, Mr Mickey Mouse, strictly against instructions. Now, I think it's time you saw some more of it. A little closer to. Ellis, take the gentleman's coat, would ya?
Why, it'd be a pleasure, boss.
Coat pulled. MOUSE whines.
Open the chute, Ellis.
No, no! Ph-phantom, please...
Don't call me that!
Mr Chaney. It - it was...
Punch.
Go on, wise guy, there's...
Chute opened.
... some thing we'd like you to meet.
No... No...
ELLIS laughs. MOUSE screams.
No! Ellis!
Bon voy-agee!
No!
Sliding down chute. Creature growling. MOUSE screams. DON CHANEY/ELLIS laugh.
I think our friend was hungry tonight.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
MAN ON RADIO: ... We present a talk by Professor John Morritz of the University of Minnesota entitled, The New Deal, Where Next. Later, it's a month now since the celebrated meteor lit up our skies. What was it? Where did it go?
MOUSE: Would you get moving, you great lunk?
ELLIS: Hey, hey! You can't hurry genius, my friend. Know what The Phantom says? There's a fine art to successful chicanery.
MOUSE: Ah, you don't even know what that means. Besides Ellis, we're breaking into a dime store. This ain't no bank heist. And we shouldn't even be doing this.
ELLIS: I've told you, Mousey, it's just insurance.
MOUSE: Jeez, if the boss knew we had some of the merchandise...
ELLIS: Yeah well, he ain't gonna know. Not until it's too late anyways.
THE DOCTOR: Well, it's the historical repercussions, you see. The beat of one bat's wing eventually leads to a tropical storm. That sort of thing. Or was it a butterfly?
CHARLEY POLLARD: And that's what happened with ... what's his name...
THE DOCTOR: Canute. He got a bit above himself, declared himself so powerful, he could turn back the tide.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Oh yes, I remember reading that somewhere. Listen, we are still heading for Singapore, aren't we?
THE DOCTOR: Of course. Now, history records the King getting soggy ankles, but not until I'd intervened. Someone had been meddling.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Who?
THE DOCTOR: One TARDIS, one twenty-fourth century Pulfidian Flood Controller, and an amoral Time Lord later, King Canute really did turn back the tide. And our friend had an unshakeable power base in Anglo Saxon Britain. Mucking about with Time is a risky business. I wouldn't recommend it to anyone.
ELLIS: What's the time?
MOUSE: Er ... eleven thirty. Ellis?
ELLIS: He should be here.
HALLIDAY: I'm here.
MOUSE: Jeez!
HALLIDAY: You got it?
ELLIS: Yeah. I got it.
HALLIDAY: Let me see.
ELLIS: Uh-uh. There are two sides to every bargain, old pal of mine. Say...
HALLIDAY: I'm only asking to see what I'm paying for.
ELLIS: Why don't you step out here into the light, Mister, and we can have a good look at you.
HALLIDAY: I don't think so.
MOUSE: Ellis, who is this wise guy?
ELLIS: Out here where I can see you. Or nobody gets nothin’.
HALLIDAY: Very well.
ELLIS: Hey!
MOUSE: Oh God...
HALLIDAY: Let's shed a little light on those pretty mugs of yours. Well, well. Mr Mouse and Mr Ellis. Nice to renew our acquaintance.
MOUSE: Halliday, we was just...
ELLIS: Shut up.
MOUSE: I'm just trying to explain to Mr Halliday, Ellis, that...
ELLIS: I said shut up. What the hell are you doin’ here, Halliday?
HALLIDAY: Not ... quite what you were expecting, eh Ellis? Hands against the wall.
MOUSE: Oh, do as he says.
HALLIDAY: Ellis?
MOUSE: When are you...?
MOUSE: Oh no, Ellis. Put that thing away.
HALLIDAY: Do I have to get nasty, Mr Ellis? Come out here where I can see you and get your damned hands up against that wall.
MOUSE: Ellis, for Christ sakes!
HALLIDAY: You wanna play hardball, wise guy, huh? This pistol belonged to my Dad. He never missed.
HALLIDAY: And neither do I.
ELLIS: Yeah? Yeah? And this ain't no Hallowe'en pop gun.
MOUSE: Oh, Jesus, Ellis.
ELLIS: Move.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Which is where you came in.
THE DOCTOR: In the nick of time, or thereabouts.
THE DOCTOR: Put things back in their proper place. The King had to go through it all again, and this time...
CHARLEY POLLARD: ...The tide came in. (Laughs.) What a silly...
THE DOCTOR: Canute? I'll say. Charley!
DRIVER: You lousy jaywalking citizen!
CHARLEY POLLARD: Singapore, Nineteen Thirty?
THE DOCTOR: Perhaps, let me see. Thirty Fourth Street and Broadway. Ah.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Not Singapore.
THE DOCTOR: Well, judging by that skyline and that taxi-driver's language...
CHARLEY POLLARD: And that ... dead man.
THE DOCTOR: And that dead man ... Oh. I'd have to say New York City.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Ladies and gentlemen, I have a grave announcement to make. Incredible as it may seem, both the observations of science and the evidence of our eyes lead to the inescapable assumption that those strange beings who landed in the Jersey Farmlands tonight, are the vanguard of an invading army from the planet Mars.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Huh?
ORSON WELLES: Who wrote this crap? I certainly didn't write this crap.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: You will, Orson, you will.
ORSON WELLES: The vanguard of an invading army - hogwash. We'd be better off pulling the whole thing, Jack.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: What would you prefer, dear boy - Lorna Doone?
ORSON WELLES: Well, why not? I can think of nothing more suitable for Hallowe'en except perhaps for - Little Lord Fauntleroy, now there's a thought.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Really Orson, now is not the time. Let's just get Howard's little play over and done and then we can concentrate on the important stuff.
ORSON WELLES: Danton's death.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: As you say, dear boy.
ORSON WELLES: Mm.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Anyway, I like the news report idea, I think it's rather neat.
ORSON WELLES: That's because you thought of it. Who'll be listening to us in any case? That damn ventriloquist is on.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: I know.
ORSON WELLES: Why do we bother?
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Because Campbell's Soup pay us to. Now, you must think of yourself like Mr Bergen's little wooden friend, and get back in your box, Orson. I'm not letting you out of this studio until rehearsals are over.
ORSON WELLES: This is Orson Welles, ladies and gentlemen, out of character to assure you that The War of the Worlds has no further significance than as the holiday offering it was intended to be. The Mercury Theatre's own radio version of dressing up in a sheet and...
ORSON WELLES: (speaker) ... jumping out of a bush and saying "boo".
BIX BIRO: God...
ORSON WELLES: (speaker) Starting now we couldn't soap all your windows and steal all your garden gates...
CARLA: What? Is that you?
BIX BIRO: What are you trying to do?
CARLA: Heavens, I'm sorry, Mr Biro, I saw the light, I figured someone must have forgot to lock the studio up.
BIX BIRO: Yeah - No, no - no, Carla. I'm just fixing some equipment, for Mr Welles.
CARLA: Just like the old times, eh sir?
BIX BIRO: (laugh) Yeah, yeah, yeah.
CARLA: They still in there, sir? Them and the Martians? (laugh.)
BIX BIRO: What? Oh. Oh, yeah.
CARLA: (laugh) I don't know what they make all the fuss about. I mean, I see little green men all the time. All it takes is just a few hours with my old friend Jack Daniels. Not that I would, I wouldn't...
BIX BIRO: That's okay, Carla. I'll see you in the morning.
CARLA: Yeah, goodnight, Mr Biro, sorry. Sorry I startled you.

THE DOCTOR: I wouldn't mind having another look inside that hotel, though.
GLORY BEE: You think she's there?
THE DOCTOR: Possibly. I'd also like to try one of their sidecars. I've a weakness for Manhattan cocktails.
GLORY BEE: You're forgetting something.
THE DOCTOR: I am?
GLORY BEE: The door.
THE DOCTOR: Please.
GLORY BEE: We're you a housebreaker before you became a detective?
THE DOCTOR: No, but I've been intimately involved with more cell doors than you've had...
GLORY BEE: Dead men?
THE DOCTOR: I was going to say hot dinners.
GLORY BEE: I've had a few.
THE DOCTOR: And yet you stay so slim. What's your secret?
GLORY BEE: Clean living. What's yours?
THE DOCTOR: Oh, every now and again I treat myself to a complete makeover.
THE DOCTOR: Let's go.
CHARLEY POLLARD: And he's got some kind of hold over your ... your friend.
WINKLER: Yeah. Bix has some ... unwholesome connections. Mobsters, mainly. I guess Devine thinks he can find out where this space stuff is being kept.
COSMO DEVINE: Good evening to you.
CHARLEY POLLARD: What's going on here? I mean, honestly, can't a person walk down the street without being kidnapped these days?
COSMO DEVINE: Hush now.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Why are you keeping me here?
CHARLEY POLLARD: Oh! What the...
WINKLER: Leave her alone!
COSMO DEVINE: Don't struggle.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Oh, I don't believe this. Will you let me go?
COSMO DEVINE: I'm afraid not. Not until you've answered fully one or two questions which I must put to you.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Who are you?
COSMO DEVINE: The Boogey-Man, sweetheart. Now, tell me about your interest in Professor Stepashin and a little matter of New York City's illustrious new visitors.
CHARLEY POLLARD: I don't know what you're talking about.
COSMO DEVINE: Oh, come on. We are not children.
COSMO DEVINE: Sadly, it may prove necessary to inject a little ... something to speed the process along.
CHARLEY POLLARD: No!
COSMO DEVINE: Will you hold out your arm, please? Or do I have to get nasty?
CHARLEY POLLARD: No!
CHARLEY POLLARD: "PHILLIPS": (radio) most terrifying thing I've ever witnessed.
COSMO DEVINE: Oh...
COSMO DEVINE: "PHILLIPS": (radio) Wait a minute...
COSMO DEVINE: I almost forgot.
COSMO DEVINE: "PHILLIPS": (radio) Someone's crawling out of the hollow top ... some one, or ... some thing...
COSMO DEVINE: Happy Hallowe'en.
COSMO DEVINE: "PHILLIPS": (radio) ... two luminous discs ... Are they eyes? It might be a face, it might be...
THE DOCTOR: Shine the light, would you?
GLORY BEE: This looks promising.
THE DOCTOR: Well, it's certainly the sort of place I'd knock up if I were in the Professor's line of work. Nice equipment.
GLORY BEE: I bet you say that to all the girls.
THE DOCTOR: Actually, no. Look.
GLORY BEE: What is it?
THE DOCTOR: Do you know what that is?
GLORY BEE: Nota clue.
THE DOCTOR: Nor me.
GLORY BEE: Oh.
THE DOCTOR: But this I do know and this is very familiar.
GLORY BEE: I'm all ears.
THE DOCTOR: They're part of the drive system from a star ship.
GLORY BEE: Star ship?
THE DOCTOR: Extraterrestrial, or I'm a Dutchman.
GLORY BEE: Extra... You mean...?
THE DOCTOR: Not of this Earth, Miss Glory Bee. Quite a thought, isn't it?
GLORY BEE: Someone's coming. Quickly.
THE DOCTOR: Lights!
THE DOCTOR: Behind this. Get your head down.
GLORY BEE: Doctor...
THE DOCTOR: Shh!
STEPASHIN: Ah ... ah-hah ... Yes, yes, Mm, mm, yes.
THE DOCTOR: Is that your uncle?
GLORY BEE: That's Professor Stepashin, yes.
THE DOCTOR: Well, what are we waiting for?
GLORY BEE: No, wait, wait.
STEPASHIN: And how is my patient?
STEPASHIN: It's getting murky in there, like a dirty goldfish bowl, eh my friend? I cannot see you in there, but ... you are getting well, yes?
STEPASHIN: I do not think I will be trying to take your temperature just yet.
THE DOCTOR: What's the matter? He's your Uncle, isn't he? This'll be a nice reunion.
GLORY BEE: Let's wait, see if we can find out more about who kidnapped him.
THE DOCTOR: Well, why don't we just ask him? Professor Stepashin?
STEPASHIN: What is this? Who...?
THE DOCTOR: I'm sorry to startle you. I'm the Doctor, and I've brought a visitor. Glory?
STEPASHIN: What do you think you're ... Who are you people?
THE DOCTOR: I'm just a tourist, but this lady needs no introduction, surely?
STEPASHIN: What?
THE DOCTOR: Your niece.
STEPASHIN: I have no family. Where is Chaney? What the hell is going on?
GLORY BEE: Sorry, Doc. I guess I ought to thank you for leading me to the Professor.
THE DOCTOR: Oh, not at all.
STEPASHIN: You have come for me?
GLORY BEE: It's nothing personal. I'm doing it for Mother Russia.

elements.text: PART THREE
Opening Doctor Who theme tune, arranged by David Arnold.
Metallic door slides open.
Shine the light, would you?
This looks promising.
Metal door closes.
Well, it's certainly the sort of place I'd knock up if I were in the Professor's line of work. Nice equipment.
I bet you say that to all the girls.
Actually, no. Look.
Object examined.
What is it?
Do you know what that is?
Nota clue.
Nor me.
Oh.
But this I do know and this is very familiar.
I'm all ears.
They're part of the drive system from a star ship.
Star ship?
Extraterrestrial, or I'm a Dutchman.
Extra... You mean...?
Not of this Earth, Miss Glory Bee. Quite a thought, isn't it?
Someone's coming. Quickly.
Lights!
Running off.
Behind this. Get your head down.
Doctor...
Shh!
Door opened.
Ah ... ah-hah ... Yes, yes, Mm, mm, yes.
Bubbling liquids.
Is that your uncle?
That's Professor Stepashin, yes.
Well, what are we waiting for?
No, wait, wait.
And how is my patient?
Something opened with a hiss.
It's getting murky in there, like a dirty goldfish bowl, eh my friend? I cannot see you in there, but ... you are getting well, yes?
Tapping on glass.
I do not think I will be trying to take your temperature just yet.
Door sealed.
What's the matter? He's your Uncle, isn't he? This'll be a nice reunion.
Let's wait, see if we can find out more about who kidnapped him.
Well, why don't we just ask him? Professor Stepashin?
What is this? Who...?
Walking over.
I'm sorry to startle you. I'm the Doctor, and I've brought a visitor. Glory?
What do you think you're ... Who are you people?
I'm just a tourist, but this lady needs no introduction, surely?
What?
Your niece.
I have no family. Where is Chaney? What the hell is going on?
Gun cocked.
Sorry, Doc. I guess I ought to thank you for leading me to the Professor.
Oh, not at all.
You have come for me?
GLORY BEE now speaks in Russian accent.
It's nothing personal. I'm doing it for Mother Russia.
Door being opened.
(radio) ...Martian machine, standing somewhere in Central Park, gleaming in the late afternoon Summer...
CHARLEY POLLARD groan of wakening.
Mr Ellis, how kind of you to join us.
I can't stay long. Chaney's getting suspicious. She talked yet?
Incessantly. Isn't that right, Mr Winkler?
Why, you no good son of a...
Turn! Turn back the tide. Turn it back.
What's she talking about?
Don't have a clue. Tide? Could be something to do with heavy water research. Stepashin's line?
Maybe she's CIA.
I don't think so. Okay, Sleeping Beauty, one more time. Who sent you?
No-one sent me ... I came with the Doctor ... It's my time, you see...
Your time?
Who is this Doctor?
We came in a time machine.
CHARLEY POLLARD chuckles.
Could be a hophead, for all we know.
Shut up. This doctor, what does he want? Does he know about the space creature?
He knows all about space creatures. He'll stop the meddling. Can't turn back the tide, Canute.
CHARLEY POLLARD laughs.
Canute?
Code name?
Turn up the radio.
(radio) .. at Sixtieth Street, and from there I could see, standing in a silent row along the mall, nineteen of those great metal Titans...
Why do you want to listen to this?
I'm waiting for a signal, Mr Ellis.
Sound of loud engine overhead.
What the hell was that!
(Noise of spaceship door opening, walking on metal. Two aliens, NORIAM's voice more high-pitched that STREATH.)
Situation, Conserver Noriam?
Decimation pattern concluded. And as estimated, Destroyer Streath, we are only a short distance from the stranded breeding party.
That is acceptable. What is the native life form?

Ah ... our reports are regrettably vague. No visits recorded. However a brief techno-scan prior to landfall reveals evidence of a heavily-industrialised pre-fission civilisation. Abundant mineral wealth, precious metals ... oh, and a lot of water.
Hmph!
Indigenous life unrecorded.
Then we must record some. Before we shatter this planet to dust!
STREATH sighs in ecstasy.
I haven't been very bright, have I?
Bright enough to find the Professor. I'm obliged.
What do you get out of all of this?
She has come to bring me home.
Is that not a good place to be?
Hah! Home to your Gulags, your camps. This is the future that Mother Russia offers me.
Come, we must get out of here. Walk, please.
Walking on metal, automatic door opening, walking.
You were going to defect.
I do not know the term.
We suspected the Professor was planning to ... extend his trip to the United States a little. It is important that such a mind as his remain within the Soviet Union.
But you lost him, didn't you?
Somebody made away with him, yes. We decided to try any means of discovering his whereabouts, even down to hiring disgusting Capitalist private detective! No offence, Mr Halliday.
None taken, I'm not Halliday, he's dead.
Then it seems we have both been playing games.
Shh!
Walking continues.
But you don't understand. Neither of you can. This is no longer about politics. What is in that room will change the world.
Alien technology, I know.
Yes, and already I have used it to advance my studies in atomic fission. It will be of incredible benefit to Mankind.
Or finish off Mankind altogether.
Not just the wonderful machines of these space creatures, one of the creatures themselves.
What?
Back there, back there in the tank.
GLORY BEE laughs.
This is all to the good. Now I shall return the Professor to Moscow, along with his astounding trinkets.
I imagine they're pretty heavy. How do you propose...?
Once we are out of here, I shall make contact with my people. They will arrive in force. Now, through here, if you please.
Metal door opened. Shipping machinery operating within.
What is this?
Well, well. I've seen some secret headquarters in my time. A headquarters inside the Brooklyn Bridge.

Suddenly my eyes were attracted to the immense flock of black birds that hovered directly below me. They circled to the ground and there before my eyes, stark and silent, lay the Martians. With the hungry birds pecking and tearing brown shreds of flesh from their dead bodies. Later when their bodies were examined in the laboratories, it was found that they were killed by the putrefactive and disease bacteria against which their systems were unprepared...
Bleeps.
(speaker) Slain, after all Man's defences had failed...
What's that, Carla?
I don't know, sir.
(speaker) ...by the humblest thing that God in his wisdom put upon this Earth.
Very nice, Orson.
Telephone ring. Receiver lifted.
Yeah? ... What? What did you say? You're kidding. What!
Carla?
Receiver replaced.
It's the switchboards, Mr Houseman. They're jammed.
You mean somebody's listening?
You could put it that way, sir. They ... they think it's real.
Door opened Walking in.
Oh boy! You've really done it this time!
Sounds of shipping in the background.
Most ingenious.
Ingenious indeed. Discreet, and yet handy for town.
There is no time for this. The Professor and I must be going. To the victor, the spoils, eh? In this case, the Soviet Union. Doctor, you are free to go.
That's very kind of you, but I'm afraid I'd rather stick around. As I've explained, I can't really allow that technology to fall into anyone's hands.
Walking over.
Least of all a lousy Red.
Alien gun powered up.
Now, let's not do anything hasty.
You're the two Ellis found at the hotel?
Yes.
The ones he told me were locked up?
Yes.
Would you recommend I get myself a new second-in-command?
Probably. Now listen, Mr ... Chaney, isn't it?
That's right. So youse is the Russkies, huh?
No, no, the lady is a ... is a Russkie, I'm just an interested observer.
Observer, huh? Never sit on fences, my friend. It makes your eyes water.
All right, Mr Chaney, I'm not an observer, I'm an active participant. Now, listen to me. We both know what kind of a precarious state the world is in currently.
Uh-huh...
Gun powered down.
Then I implore you, whatever deal you've made, forget it. This stuff is too dangerous to give to anyone right now.
But I made a deal, Mr...
Doctor.
Doctor. Don Chaney made a deal with the good guys, how about that? The
are on their way to a cosy rendezvous. I'm packing up my troubles and I'm gonna give them all that space junk downstairs.
At least he has not sold it to the Nazis.
But it belongs to us. The Professor has sustained this creature, analysed the technology. I claim it all!
DON CHANEY laughs.
Are you kiddin’?

What do you think this is, Pass The Parcel? We're talking about technology that is thousands of years in advance of what you have on Earth. The Professor here has already adapted what he's learned to help with his fission experiments.
Yes. Yes, I have constructed a prototype. I believe it will work. Think of it. An atomic bomb.
I am thinking of it. Now please, Mr Chaney, Professor, Miss Bee or whoever you are, let it go. Believe me, it's for the best. I can take care of this.

And who are youse, huh? Santy Claus? Say, are you English? Is that why you're giving us all this hope and charity stuff? Yeah, that's it. Your Mr Chamberlain wants to get his paws on it first. Well, no dice, Doctor.
Running over.
Boss! Boss!
Hey, you're just in time. Tell Ellis he's fired.
Listen boss, it's on the radio. Everyone's talking about it.
Talking about what?
Men from Space, boss. They're here.
We know that, you klutz. What do you think this whole goddamn circus is about?
No, no, not that man from Space, boss. Some other man from Space.
What?
Martians. The Martians have landed!
I sincerely hope not.
(radio) ... in vain for the monsters that inhabit those machines.
Radio turned off.
That was the signal?
That's correct, Mr Ellis. The signal telling me I can toddle along to the CBS and pick up the information I require.
CHARLEY POLLARD groans.
Ah - ah ... I think she's coming out of it.
Really. It's of small consequence.
I-information? What information?
The alien. Where it's being kept.
Why .,.. but how can you...
Gun powered up.
No. You need me, Devine. I got you all this merchandise.
And I'm probably grateful. Alas, you wouldn't divulge its location and so I had to find someone else who'd tell me.
You ... you double-crossed me.
Naturally. My grandmother taught me two things in life. Never wash taffeta with cotton, and never put all your eggs in one basket. I have to say, the latter has been of most use to me.
You know where the spaceman is.

I will very shortly. I've been keeping this young man in my house. "Plus @a change...", I hear you cry. But this one was staying very much against his will, I'm afraid. His nearest and dearest is very keen to get him back.
Blackmail.
Well, hello. Yes, blackmail. What do they say in the movies? It's an ugly word? Well, it's an ugly world too, my friend, as you will shortly find out.
Gun powered up higher.
You're crazy, Devine! What if your guy doesn't come up with the address? Then what? I'm your only hope.
It's a chance I'll take, if only to spare myself your dazzling conversation. Ta-ta.
No!
Running over, struggle.
Why, you...
Laser gun fired, explosion, WINKLER crying out.
Chair, quick!
What?
Hit him with the chair!
Noise of chair being hit/obreaking and COSMO DEVINE gasp. Humming of laser gun.
Now, cut Jimmy loose or I'll shoot.
It's no good. The ray gun must have got him. He's a goner.
Oh ... Oh, all right. Let's go. Move.
Walking out.
We can't stand around here all night.
I gotta protect my investment, Doctor. The CIA want the Professor here as well. Maybe they'll want you too. You science guys fetch quite a few cents, I can tell you. Now, drop the gun, sister.
Hah! I am trained Soviet agent. I do not disarm myself because some stupid Yankee gangster threatens me.
Uh. I'll count to three.
Please, stop this.
Hand over the Prof and you can go home to Siberia and play with your dolls.
You know, we have skilled surgeons in Soviet Union. They could do something about that face of yours.
Uh, sticks and stones. Now, what's all this about Martians?
I've no idea. I would imagine that whoever lost his alien ship has come back to find it and ... Wait a minute. What year is this?
Oh, now I heard it all.
Nineteen Thirty-Eight, yes?
October Thirty-First, why?
Martians, hmm?
THE DOCTOR laughs.
They're going crazy, Houseman. What the hell did you think you were doing?
We none of us expected this, Mr Biro.
Telephone rings. Receiver lifted.
Yes? What? Oh, for Christ sakes.
Receiver put down.
The whole place is under siege, you dumb ass! As if I didn't have enough on my ... Is that clock right?
Of course.

Okay. You're off the air in five. Now, I'm expecting a ... very important visitor. I want you to get that young idiot in there to apologise to the people of America for scaring the bejesus out of 'em, and then, I want to see both of you in my office.
Walking off.
Martians. Jesus!
Door closed.
All right, Carla. Better write something appropriate for young Mr Welles. Lock that door, would you? I've a feeling it's ... gonna be a long night.
Panic crowd screams, traffic jam noises.
The Martians are coming! The Martians are coming! They're coming!
They're here already, lady. Jersey's been blowed.
Oh my Lord.
Running.
Oh, keep moving, you fat fool.
I'm ... I'm gonna wring your neck, little lady.
Humming sound of alien ship.
What the...
CHARLEY POLLARD gasps.
Do you see what I see?
L-let's get out of here.
What was that? Seize them.
Wings flapping, Bat-like screeches.
Oh my God! Get off me, get away!
Holy Mother...
Destroy, destroy, destroy!
Wait, wait.
You dare to question me?
It is my right as a brother Laiderblacker to question you, Streath. I am merely suggesting that we record the life-form before its destruction.
Destruction is good, Noriam. To destroy is the Second Principle.
And the joint Second Principle is conservation. That is our way. Do I have to explain to you as I would to a child?
Yes, yes! The middle way, I know. Between destruction and conservation lies wisdom, yes...
Precisely. Now, would it not be wise to gauge the strength of the native creatures by examining them?
There is some sense in your words, Noriam. Their destruction shall be postponed.
Thank you.
Postponed, mind you. Now...
STREATH hisses
Ahh...!
CHARLEY POLLARD gasps.
They're very little, are they not?
Indeed, Streath. Keep still, beast!
ELLIS gasps.
And ... and without much hair. It is a poor thing to be so hairless. What are you called, hairless thing? Ahh...!
Ch... Ch... Charley.
Are you an overlord of this place, Ch-Ch-Charley, or an underling?
CHARLEY POLLARD gasps.
Answer! Your destruction has merely been postponed.
I don't understand.
May I?
STREATH growls.
Now, what is this place called?
I haven't a clue.
You, then. What is this place called?
N... New Jersey.
And what are your defensive capabilities?
Eh?
(Sigh.) Is N-New Jersey the place where your weapons are kept?
No, sir. I guess that'd be in ... in the city.
Shut up, Ellis.
The city.
Manhattan. Just across the water.
Water? Ah yes.
You, er ... need, erm ... the Staten Island ferry.
Just so, Noriam?
Yes.
This city. This must be where the breeding party crashed. Tracking must begin at once, and prepare for takeoff.
Very well.
Well done, Ellis.
And you will come with us, hairless things. You may prove useful. We'll take Manhattan, and Staten Island too.
STREATH laughs.
Three knocks, door opened. Traffic chaos in background.
I had quite a bit of trouble getting in here, Mr Biro. Is there a Mardi Gras going on?
Look, never mind that. Did anyone see you come in?
Nota soul. I followed your instructions to the letter. And I got your signal. Ingenious.
Yeah, yeah, well ... I was a sound engineer before they put me behind this desk. It wasn't very difficult to arrange.
You have the location?
I got it. Now, where's Jimmy ... Mr Winkler?
He's safe. He'll be released as soon as we leave here.
How do I know...?
That he'll be all right? You don't. I guess you'll just have to trust me.
Okay. Okay. The spaceship or whatever crash-landed in Brooklyn. The CIA were onto it like flies round a wound, but the local mobsters got there first, a fella called...
Chaney. Don Chaney. Known as The Phantom.
You know all this?
Naturally. One of Mr Chaney's thugs was until recently in my employ. And I have a few scores still to settle with him. All I need is the address.
(laugh) It's not quite an address. Chaney's base is inside the left leg of the Brooklyn Bridge. Manhattan side.
Thank you. I knew I could rely on those rather dubious underworld
contacts of yours. I'm sure no-one need hear of them now.
Devine, you'll let Jimmy go?
I only wish I could, Mr Biro, but he met with an accident a short time ago.
Why, you...
Oh, there's just one more thing.
Shot fired from a gun with a silencer. BIX BIRO gasps, two more shots from the silencer.
That's Mr Devine to you.
Door closes. BIX BIRO gasps. Sound of the words of a tape rewinding.
Here. Take this. These rays guns is heavy.
Sure, boss.
Look, over there, heading towards us.
Yeah, yeah, I know all the tricks, Doctor.
I'm serious...
Whine of space craft overhead.
My God!
We've got company, Mr Chaney.
What is it?
A version of the ship I imagine you have in pieces down below. It's probably...
Get back, all of you.
Lady?
The Professor comes with me.
Let him go.
Gun powered up.
Now, now - don't shoot.
Laser gun shots. GLORY BEE screams.
Hang on, take my hand.
GLORY BEE cry out.
Take it.
I can't ... I can't hold on.
Chaney, help me.
GLORY BEE gasp.
Okay, okay. Here lady, grab hold of my arm.
No good...
GLORY BEE scream, fades away.
Oh no!
Eventual splash.
Jeez. She was a looker too. Okay, you wise guys - downstairs.
Gun powered down. Walking downstairs.
Well, Miss Bee, I hope it was worth it, all for Mother Russia.
Humming and bleeps as though inside a spaceship.
Energy weapon fired outside at close quarters, Streath. I think we've found them.
There is a body of water below, yes?
According to our scans.
Then put us down there.
That's the Brooklyn Bridge down there. I may still have a chance.
A chance for what?
To make good. I gotta warn Chaney. Devine is after him. He'll be down here with his men as soon as he knows about the bridge. If I can warn Chaney...
Why are you so concerned about Chaney? You were selling him out, weren't you?
Ah, it was business, that's all, I ... I thought I was just using my initiative. I never told him where the boss has his headquarters.
Huh! Bully for you. I bet your precious Mr Chaney won't be in a forgiving mood.
I owe him everything. How can I sell him down the river to a goddamn Nazi.
If the breeding party is intact, then how are we to proceed?
As usual, of course, Streath. I'm afraid destruction may have to be indefinitely postponed.
Oh, it's always the same.
Keep your voice down, Streath. We must appear invincible to these creatures.
Metal door opened.
Okay, get inside.
Walking in.
Hell, where is everybody? Ellis? Ellis! You, go see what's up.
Yes, boss.
What about ... the Martians?
They're not Martians. Oh, this is extraordinary.
What is?
I think I Know what's going on, and it's quite an amusing coincidence.
Do you see me laughing?
Door opened, walking in.
Well, isn't this nice.
What the hell...?
You must think me such a bore, Mr Chaney. It is Mr Chaney, isn't it? I arrive unannounced, gatecrash your little party and then spirit away your special guests.
Lots of guns cocked.
Steady, boys.
Who are you?
Cosmo Devine. Perhaps you've read my articles in the Tatler.
Listen to me, you lousy faggot. I made a deal for all this space junk and I gave them my word. Don Chaney's word is his bond.
How touching. Well, well, time and tide, time and tide. My associates and I will have to be going. Soldier, get this machinery out of here, then kill them all.
Jawohl!
Soldier?
I think Mr Devine's associates are representatives of an unfriendly power, Mr Chaney.
Oh, didn't I mention? How remiss. Yes, they're Germans. Pure, one
hundred per cent. Unlike me. I'm just what they call a sympathiser.
Lousy Fifth Columnist.
Just a gossip columnist, actually. Incidentally, I've always wondered, what do the other four columns do?
Devine, I implore you not to do this. If you give Nazi Germany this technology...
Da, da. This is what I have been saying.
Well, you'll forgive me for being obvious, but that is rather the point, isn't it? They'll be unbeatable. Flying disc ships, death rays. I think they'll have the opposition beat.
I can't let you do it.
Well, boo-hoo. Just how are you going to stop me?
Hiss noise as tank is opened.
What are you doing? You mustn't unseal the tank.
I'm afraid my pals in Berlin aren't worried about the spacemen, Prof. They just want the guns.
But it is priceless, priceless!
My heart bleeds. Okay, junk it, soldier.
Loud hissing.
Oh dear.
I can't see anything. Do you think it is dead?
No.
What are you waiting for, Fritzy? Christmas? Get the thing out of there and we'll split.
Es ist schrecklich!
[Translation - "it is horrible."]
Hey-ho. If you want something doing. Here, give me that gun.
Hissing of alien creature.
What in God's...?
How many creatures did you say were in the tank, Professor?
One. One only.
Look.
Hissing.
Oh no.
Hissing.
I think something else has been doing the splitting, Mr Devine. Binary fission. It's been reproducing.
There are?
Yes. There must be thirty of them.
Screeching of aliens.
End of part three on CD.
Oh my God!
Right, everybody out.
Shots fired.
Chaney, through the door, come on.
Shots.
Okay. I made mistake. Now...
Door closed, muffling the sound.
We can't just leave them in there.
Watch me. Where's the Professor?
Still inside, I'm afraid. You've got to get him out.
Your loyalty is touching, but a little misplaced. In case you haven't noticed, there's a bunch of giant fruitbats in there making short work of the Fuhrer's finest.
We have to try.
You forget...
Gun powered up.
I still have this little baby.
I'm going back for him.
Door opened, louder sound of battle.
Watch it.
Professor.
Are you crazy?
Leave me.
Get a gun and shoot them, Prof. Come on!
I cannot. They are magnificent. Magnificent.
STEPASHIN screams. Door closed.
Enough! I won't warn you a second time.
THE DOCTOR sighs.
What now, Mr Devine? You've come away rather empty-handed, haven't you?
Shut up, I'm thinking.
Muffled scream from beyond. Gun powered up.
Okay dokey, get moving, both of you.
Walking.
What ... what are those things, Doctor?
I haven't the foggiest. Mammalian, certainly, as our friend here put it so colourfully, they're like some form of giant bat. That sound.
But they're so ... savage. How could creatures like that...?
Yes, that had occurred to me too. They do act a little ... brusquely for supposedly intelligent creatures.
Well, they're young, aren't they? You know what young carnivorous alien mammal-like monsters are like. Always getting into scrapes.
And you think someone's coming to find them?
I do, and I have a nasty feeling that the grown-ups are even worse.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
THE DOCTOR: Shine the light, would you?
GLORY BEE: This looks promising.
THE DOCTOR: Well, it's certainly the sort of place I'd knock up if I were in the Professor's line of work. Nice equipment.
GLORY BEE: I bet you say that to all the girls.
THE DOCTOR: Actually, no. Look.
GLORY BEE: What is it?
THE DOCTOR: Do you know what that is?
GLORY BEE: Nota clue.
THE DOCTOR: Nor me.
GLORY BEE: Oh.
THE DOCTOR: But this I do know and this is very familiar.
GLORY BEE: I'm all ears.
THE DOCTOR: They're part of the drive system from a star ship.
GLORY BEE: Star ship?
THE DOCTOR: Extraterrestrial, or I'm a Dutchman.
GLORY BEE: Extra... You mean...?
THE DOCTOR: Not of this Earth, Miss Glory Bee. Quite a thought, isn't it?
GLORY BEE: Someone's coming. Quickly.
THE DOCTOR: Lights!
THE DOCTOR: Behind this. Get your head down.
GLORY BEE: Doctor...
THE DOCTOR: Shh!
STEPASHIN: Ah ... ah-hah ... Yes, yes, Mm, mm, yes.
THE DOCTOR: Is that your uncle?
GLORY BEE: That's Professor Stepashin, yes.
THE DOCTOR: Well, what are we waiting for?
GLORY BEE: No, wait, wait.
STEPASHIN: And how is my patient?
STEPASHIN: It's getting murky in there, like a dirty goldfish bowl, eh my friend? I cannot see you in there, but ... you are getting well, yes?
STEPASHIN: I do not think I will be trying to take your temperature just yet.
THE DOCTOR: What's the matter? He's your Uncle, isn't he? This'll be a nice reunion.
GLORY BEE: Let's wait, see if we can find out more about who kidnapped him.
THE DOCTOR: Well, why don't we just ask him? Professor Stepashin?
STEPASHIN: What is this? Who...?
THE DOCTOR: I'm sorry to startle you. I'm the Doctor, and I've brought a visitor. Glory?
STEPASHIN: What do you think you're ... Who are you people?
THE DOCTOR: I'm just a tourist, but this lady needs no introduction, surely?
STEPASHIN: What?
THE DOCTOR: Your niece.
STEPASHIN: I have no family. Where is Chaney? What the hell is going on?
GLORY BEE: Sorry, Doc. I guess I ought to thank you for leading me to the Professor.
THE DOCTOR: Oh, not at all.
STEPASHIN: You have come for me?
GLORY BEE: It's nothing personal. I'm doing it for Mother Russia.
ORSON WELLES: (radio) ...Martian machine, standing somewhere in Central Park, gleaming in the late afternoon Summer...
COSMO DEVINE: Mr Ellis, how kind of you to join us.
ELLIS: I can't stay long. Chaney's getting suspicious. She talked yet?
COSMO DEVINE: Incessantly. Isn't that right, Mr Winkler?
WINKLER: Why, you no good son of a...
CHARLEY POLLARD: Turn! Turn back the tide. Turn it back.
ELLIS: What's she talking about?
COSMO DEVINE: Don't have a clue. Tide? Could be something to do with heavy water research. Stepashin's line?
ELLIS: Maybe she's CIA.
COSMO DEVINE: I don't think so. Okay, Sleeping Beauty, one more time. Who sent you?
CHARLEY POLLARD: No-one sent me ... I came with the Doctor ... It's my time, you see...
COSMO DEVINE: Your time?
ELLIS: Who is this Doctor?
CHARLEY POLLARD: We came in a time machine.
ELLIS: Could be a hophead, for all we know.
COSMO DEVINE: Shut up. This doctor, what does he want? Does he know about the space creature?
CHARLEY POLLARD: He knows all about space creatures. He'll stop the meddling. Can't turn back the tide, Canute.
COSMO DEVINE: Canute?
ELLIS: Code name?
COSMO DEVINE: Turn up the radio.
ORSON WELLES: (radio) .. at Sixtieth Street, and from there I could see, standing in a silent row along the mall, nineteen of those great metal Titans...
ELLIS: Why do you want to listen to this?
COSMO DEVINE: I'm waiting for a signal, Mr Ellis.
ELLIS: What the hell was that!
ELLIS: (Noise of spaceship door opening, walking on metal. Two aliens, NORIAM's voice more high-pitched that STREATH.)
STREATH: Situation, Conserver Noriam?
NORIAM: Decimation pattern concluded. And as estimated, Destroyer Streath, we are only a short distance from the stranded breeding party.
STREATH: That is acceptable. What is the native life form?
NORIAM: Ah ... our reports are regrettably vague. No visits recorded. However a brief techno-scan prior to landfall reveals evidence of a heavily-industrialised pre-fission civilisation. Abundant mineral wealth, precious metals ... oh, and a lot of water.
STREATH: Hmph!
NORIAM: Indigenous life unrecorded.
STREATH: Then we must record some. Before we shatter this planet to dust!
THE DOCTOR: I haven't been very bright, have I?
GLORY BEE: Bright enough to find the Professor. I'm obliged.
THE DOCTOR: What do you get out of all of this?
STEPASHIN: She has come to bring me home.
GLORY BEE: Is that not a good place to be?
STEPASHIN: Hah! Home to your Gulags, your camps. This is the future that Mother Russia offers me.
GLORY BEE: Come, we must get out of here. Walk, please.
THE DOCTOR: You were going to defect.
STEPASHIN: I do not know the term.
GLORY BEE: We suspected the Professor was planning to ... extend his trip to the United States a little. It is important that such a mind as his remain within the Soviet Union.
THE DOCTOR: But you lost him, didn't you?
GLORY BEE: Somebody made away with him, yes. We decided to try any means of discovering his whereabouts, even down to hiring disgusting Capitalist private detective! No offence, Mr Halliday.
THE DOCTOR: None taken, I'm not Halliday, he's dead.
GLORY BEE: Then it seems we have both been playing games.
THE DOCTOR: Shh!
STEPASHIN: But you don't understand. Neither of you can. This is no longer about politics. What is in that room will change the world.
THE DOCTOR: Alien technology, I know.
STEPASHIN: Yes, and already I have used it to advance my studies in atomic fission. It will be of incredible benefit to Mankind.
THE DOCTOR: Or finish off Mankind altogether.
STEPASHIN: Not just the wonderful machines of these space creatures, one of the creatures themselves.
THE DOCTOR: What?
STEPASHIN: Back there, back there in the tank.
GLORY BEE: This is all to the good. Now I shall return the Professor to Moscow, along with his astounding trinkets.
THE DOCTOR: I imagine they're pretty heavy. How do you propose...?
GLORY BEE: Once we are out of here, I shall make contact with my people. They will arrive in force. Now, through here, if you please.
STEPASHIN: What is this?
THE DOCTOR: Well, well. I've seen some secret headquarters in my time. A headquarters inside the Brooklyn Bridge.
ORSON WELLES: Suddenly my eyes were attracted to the immense flock of black birds that hovered directly below me. They circled to the ground and there before my eyes, stark and silent, lay the Martians. With the hungry birds pecking and tearing brown shreds of flesh from their dead bodies. Later when their bodies were examined in the laboratories, it was found that they were killed by the putrefactive and disease bacteria against which their systems were unprepared...
ORSON WELLES: (speaker) Slain, after all Man's defences had failed...
JOHN HOUSEMAN: What's that, Carla?
CARLA: I don't know, sir.
ORSON WELLES: (speaker) ...by the humblest thing that God in his wisdom put upon this Earth.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Very nice, Orson.
CARLA: Yeah? ... What? What did you say? You're kidding. What!
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Carla?
CARLA: It's the switchboards, Mr Houseman. They're jammed.
JOHN HOUSEMAN: You mean somebody's listening?
CARLA: You could put it that way, sir. They ... they think it's real.
BIX BIRO: Oh boy! You've really done it this time!
STEPASHIN: Most ingenious.
THE DOCTOR: Ingenious indeed. Discreet, and yet handy for town.
GLORY BEE: There is no time for this. The Professor and I must be going. To the victor, the spoils, eh? In this case, the Soviet Union. Doctor, you are free to go.
THE DOCTOR: That's very kind of you, but I'm afraid I'd rather stick around. As I've explained, I can't really allow that technology to fall into anyone's hands.
DON CHANEY: Least of all a lousy Red.
THE DOCTOR: Now, let's not do anything hasty.
DON CHANEY: You're the two Ellis found at the hotel?
THE DOCTOR: Yes.
DON CHANEY: The ones he told me were locked up?
THE DOCTOR: Yes.
DON CHANEY: Would you recommend I get myself a new second-in-command?
THE DOCTOR: Probably. Now listen, Mr ... Chaney, isn't it?
DON CHANEY: That's right. So youse is the Russkies, huh?
THE DOCTOR: No, no, the lady is a ... is a Russkie, I'm just an interested observer.
DON CHANEY: Observer, huh? Never sit on fences, my friend. It makes your eyes water.
THE DOCTOR: All right, Mr Chaney, I'm not an observer, I'm an active participant. Now, listen to me. We both know what kind of a precarious state the world is in currently.
DON CHANEY: Uh-huh...
THE DOCTOR: Then I implore you, whatever deal you've made, forget it. This stuff is too dangerous to give to anyone right now.
DON CHANEY: But I made a deal, Mr...
THE DOCTOR: Doctor.
DON CHANEY: Doctor. Don Chaney made a deal with the good guys, how about that? The
CIA: are on their way to a cosy rendezvous. I'm packing up my troubles and I'm gonna give them all that space junk downstairs.
STEPASHIN: At least he has not sold it to the Nazis.
GLORY BEE: But it belongs to us. The Professor has sustained this creature, analysed the technology. I claim it all!
DON CHANEY: Are you kiddin’?
THE DOCTOR: What do you think this is, Pass The Parcel? We're talking about technology that is thousands of years in advance of what you have on Earth. The Professor here has already adapted what he's learned to help with his fission experiments.
STEPASHIN: Yes. Yes, I have constructed a prototype. I believe it will work. Think of it. An atomic bomb.
THE DOCTOR: I am thinking of it. Now please, Mr Chaney, Professor, Miss Bee or whoever you are, let it go. Believe me, it's for the best. I can take care of this.
DON CHANEY: And who are youse, huh? Santy Claus? Say, are you English? Is that why you're giving us all this hope and charity stuff? Yeah, that's it. Your Mr Chamberlain wants to get his paws on it first. Well, no dice, Doctor.
GANGSTER: Boss! Boss!
DON CHANEY: Hey, you're just in time. Tell Ellis he's fired.
GANGSTER: Listen boss, it's on the radio. Everyone's talking about it.
DON CHANEY: Talking about what?
GANGSTER: Men from Space, boss. They're here.
DON CHANEY: We know that, you klutz. What do you think this whole goddamn circus is about?
GANGSTER: No, no, not that man from Space, boss. Some other man from Space.
THE DOCTOR: What?
GANGSTER: Martians. The Martians have landed!
THE DOCTOR: I sincerely hope not.
ORSON WELLES: (radio) ... in vain for the monsters that inhabit those machines.
ELLIS: That was the signal?
COSMO DEVINE: That's correct, Mr Ellis. The signal telling me I can toddle along to the CBS and pick up the information I require.
ELLIS: Ah - ah ... I think she's coming out of it.
COSMO DEVINE: Really. It's of small consequence.
ELLIS: I-information? What information?
WINKLER: The alien. Where it's being kept.
ELLIS: Why .,.. but how can you...
ELLIS: No. You need me, Devine. I got you all this merchandise.
COSMO DEVINE: And I'm probably grateful. Alas, you wouldn't divulge its location and so I had to find someone else who'd tell me.
ELLIS: You ... you double-crossed me.
COSMO DEVINE: Naturally. My grandmother taught me two things in life. Never wash taffeta with cotton, and never put all your eggs in one basket. I have to say, the latter has been of most use to me.
ELLIS: You know where the spaceman is.
COSMO DEVINE: I will very shortly. I've been keeping this young man in my house. "Plus @a change...", I hear you cry. But this one was staying very much against his will, I'm afraid. His nearest and dearest is very keen to get him back.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Blackmail.
COSMO DEVINE: Well, hello. Yes, blackmail. What do they say in the movies? It's an ugly word? Well, it's an ugly world too, my friend, as you will shortly find out.
ELLIS: You're crazy, Devine! What if your guy doesn't come up with the address? Then what? I'm your only hope.
COSMO DEVINE: It's a chance I'll take, if only to spare myself your dazzling conversation. Ta-ta.
CHARLEY POLLARD: No!
COSMO DEVINE: Why, you...
CHARLEY POLLARD: Chair, quick!
ELLIS: What?
CHARLEY POLLARD: Hit him with the chair!
CHARLEY POLLARD: Now, cut Jimmy loose or I'll shoot.
ELLIS: It's no good. The ray gun must have got him. He's a goner.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Oh ... Oh, all right. Let's go. Move.
THE DOCTOR: We can't stand around here all night.
DON CHANEY: I gotta protect my investment, Doctor. The CIA want the Professor here as well. Maybe they'll want you too. You science guys fetch quite a few cents, I can tell you. Now, drop the gun, sister.
GLORY BEE: Hah! I am trained Soviet agent. I do not disarm myself because some stupid Yankee gangster threatens me.
DON CHANEY: Uh. I'll count to three.
STEPASHIN: Please, stop this.
DON CHANEY: Hand over the Prof and you can go home to Siberia and play with your dolls.
GLORY BEE: You know, we have skilled surgeons in Soviet Union. They could do something about that face of yours.
DON CHANEY: Uh, sticks and stones. Now, what's all this about Martians?
THE DOCTOR: I've no idea. I would imagine that whoever lost his alien ship has come back to find it and ... Wait a minute. What year is this?
DON CHANEY: Oh, now I heard it all.
THE DOCTOR: Nineteen Thirty-Eight, yes?
STEPASHIN: October Thirty-First, why?
THE DOCTOR: Martians, hmm?
BIX BIRO: They're going crazy, Houseman. What the hell did you think you were doing?
JOHN HOUSEMAN: We none of us expected this, Mr Biro.
BIX BIRO: Yes? What? Oh, for Christ sakes.
BIX BIRO: The whole place is under siege, you dumb ass! As if I didn't have enough on my ... Is that clock right?
JOHN HOUSEMAN: Of course.
BIX BIRO: Okay. You're off the air in five. Now, I'm expecting a ... very important visitor. I want you to get that young idiot in there to apologise to the people of America for scaring the bejesus out of 'em, and then, I want to see both of you in my office.
BIX BIRO: Martians. Jesus!
JOHN HOUSEMAN: All right, Carla. Better write something appropriate for young Mr Welles. Lock that door, would you? I've a feeling it's ... gonna be a long night.
WOMAN: The Martians are coming! The Martians are coming! They're coming!
MAN: They're here already, lady. Jersey's been blowed.
WOMAN: Oh my Lord.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Oh, keep moving, you fat fool.
ELLIS: I'm ... I'm gonna wring your neck, little lady.
ELLIS: What the...
CHARLEY POLLARD: Do you see what I see?
ELLIS: L-let's get out of here.
STREATH: What was that? Seize them.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Oh my God! Get off me, get away!
ELLIS: Holy Mother...
STREATH: Destroy, destroy, destroy!
NORIAM: Wait, wait.
STREATH: You dare to question me?
NORIAM: It is my right as a brother Laiderblacker to question you, Streath. I am merely suggesting that we record the life-form before its destruction.
STREATH: Destruction is good, Noriam. To destroy is the Second Principle.
NORIAM: And the joint Second Principle is conservation. That is our way. Do I have to explain to you as I would to a child?
STREATH: Yes, yes! The middle way, I know. Between destruction and conservation lies wisdom, yes...
NORIAM: Precisely. Now, would it not be wise to gauge the strength of the native creatures by examining them?
STREATH: There is some sense in your words, Noriam. Their destruction shall be postponed.
NORIAM: Thank you.
STREATH: Postponed, mind you. Now...
STREATH: Ahh...!
STREATH: They're very little, are they not?
NORIAM: Indeed, Streath. Keep still, beast!
STREATH: And ... and without much hair. It is a poor thing to be so hairless. What are you called, hairless thing? Ahh...!
CHARLEY POLLARD: Ch... Ch... Charley.
STREATH: Are you an overlord of this place, Ch-Ch-Charley, or an underling?
STREATH: Answer! Your destruction has merely been postponed.
CHARLEY POLLARD: I don't understand.
NORIAM: May I?
NORIAM: Now, what is this place called?
CHARLEY POLLARD: I haven't a clue.
NORIAM: You, then. What is this place called?
ELLIS: N... New Jersey.
NORIAM: And what are your defensive capabilities?
ELLIS: Eh?
NORIAM: (Sigh.) Is N-New Jersey the place where your weapons are kept?
ELLIS: No, sir. I guess that'd be in ... in the city.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Shut up, Ellis.
STREATH: The city.
ELLIS: Manhattan. Just across the water.
NORIAM: Water? Ah yes.
ELLIS: You, er ... need, erm ... the Staten Island ferry.
STREATH: Just so, Noriam?
NORIAM: Yes.
STREATH: This city. This must be where the breeding party crashed. Tracking must begin at once, and prepare for takeoff.
NORIAM: Very well.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Well done, Ellis.
STREATH: And you will come with us, hairless things. You may prove useful. We'll take Manhattan, and Staten Island too.
COSMO DEVINE: I had quite a bit of trouble getting in here, Mr Biro. Is there a Mardi Gras going on?
BIX BIRO: Look, never mind that. Did anyone see you come in?
COSMO DEVINE: Nota soul. I followed your instructions to the letter. And I got your signal. Ingenious.
BIX BIRO: Yeah, yeah, well ... I was a sound engineer before they put me behind this desk. It wasn't very difficult to arrange.
COSMO DEVINE: You have the location?
BIX BIRO: I got it. Now, where's Jimmy ... Mr Winkler?
COSMO DEVINE: He's safe. He'll be released as soon as we leave here.
BIX BIRO: How do I know...?
COSMO DEVINE: That he'll be all right? You don't. I guess you'll just have to trust me.
BIX BIRO: Okay. Okay. The spaceship or whatever crash-landed in Brooklyn. The CIA were onto it like flies round a wound, but the local mobsters got there first, a fella called...
COSMO DEVINE: Chaney. Don Chaney. Known as The Phantom.
BIX BIRO: You know all this?
COSMO DEVINE: Naturally. One of Mr Chaney's thugs was until recently in my employ. And I have a few scores still to settle with him. All I need is the address.
BIX BIRO: (laugh) It's not quite an address. Chaney's base is inside the left leg of the Brooklyn Bridge. Manhattan side.
COSMO DEVINE: Thank you. I knew I could rely on those rather dubious underworld
COSMO DEVINE: contacts of yours. I'm sure no-one need hear of them now.
BIX BIRO: Devine, you'll let Jimmy go?
COSMO DEVINE: I only wish I could, Mr Biro, but he met with an accident a short time ago.
BIX BIRO: Why, you...
COSMO DEVINE: Oh, there's just one more thing.
COSMO DEVINE: That's Mr Devine to you.
DON CHANEY: Here. Take this. These rays guns is heavy.
GANGSTER: Sure, boss.
THE DOCTOR: Look, over there, heading towards us.
DON CHANEY: Yeah, yeah, I know all the tricks, Doctor.
THE DOCTOR: I'm serious...
STEPASHIN: My God!
THE DOCTOR: We've got company, Mr Chaney.
DON CHANEY: What is it?
THE DOCTOR: A version of the ship I imagine you have in pieces down below. It's probably...
GLORY BEE: Get back, all of you.
GANGSTER: Lady?
GLORY BEE: The Professor comes with me.
GANGSTER: Let him go.
DON CHANEY: Now, now - don't shoot.
THE DOCTOR: Hang on, take my hand.
THE DOCTOR: Take it.
GLORY BEE: I can't ... I can't hold on.
THE DOCTOR: Chaney, help me.
DON CHANEY: Okay, okay. Here lady, grab hold of my arm.
GLORY BEE: No good...
THE DOCTOR: Oh no!
DON CHANEY: Jeez. She was a looker too. Okay, you wise guys - downstairs.
THE DOCTOR: Well, Miss Bee, I hope it was worth it, all for Mother Russia.
NORIAM: Energy weapon fired outside at close quarters, Streath. I think we've found them.
STREATH: There is a body of water below, yes?
NORIAM: According to our scans.
STREATH: Then put us down there.
ELLIS: That's the Brooklyn Bridge down there. I may still have a chance.
CHARLEY POLLARD: A chance for what?
ELLIS: To make good. I gotta warn Chaney. Devine is after him. He'll be down here with his men as soon as he knows about the bridge. If I can warn Chaney...
CHARLEY POLLARD: Why are you so concerned about Chaney? You were selling him out, weren't you?
ELLIS: Ah, it was business, that's all, I ... I thought I was just using my initiative. I never told him where the boss has his headquarters.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Huh! Bully for you. I bet your precious Mr Chaney won't be in a forgiving mood.
ELLIS: I owe him everything. How can I sell him down the river to a goddamn Nazi.
STREATH: If the breeding party is intact, then how are we to proceed?
NORIAM: As usual, of course, Streath. I'm afraid destruction may have to be indefinitely postponed.
STREATH: Oh, it's always the same.
NORIAM: Keep your voice down, Streath. We must appear invincible to these creatures.
DON CHANEY: Okay, get inside.
DON CHANEY: Hell, where is everybody? Ellis? Ellis! You, go see what's up.
GANGSTER: Yes, boss.
STEPASHIN: What about ... the Martians?
THE DOCTOR: They're not Martians. Oh, this is extraordinary.
DON CHANEY: What is?
THE DOCTOR: I think I Know what's going on, and it's quite an amusing coincidence.
DON CHANEY: Do you see me laughing?
COSMO DEVINE: Well, isn't this nice.
DON CHANEY: What the hell...?
COSMO DEVINE: You must think me such a bore, Mr Chaney. It is Mr Chaney, isn't it? I arrive unannounced, gatecrash your little party and then spirit away your special guests.
COSMO DEVINE: Steady, boys.
THE DOCTOR: Who are you?
COSMO DEVINE: Cosmo Devine. Perhaps you've read my articles in the Tatler.
DON CHANEY: Listen to me, you lousy faggot. I made a deal for all this space junk and I gave them my word. Don Chaney's word is his bond.
COSMO DEVINE: How touching. Well, well, time and tide, time and tide. My associates and I will have to be going. Soldier, get this machinery out of here, then kill them all.
SOLDIER: Jawohl!
STEPASHIN: Soldier?
THE DOCTOR: I think Mr Devine's associates are representatives of an unfriendly power, Mr Chaney.
COSMO DEVINE: Oh, didn't I mention? How remiss. Yes, they're Germans. Pure, one
COSMO DEVINE: hundred per cent. Unlike me. I'm just what they call a sympathiser.
DON CHANEY: Lousy Fifth Columnist.
COSMO DEVINE: Just a gossip columnist, actually. Incidentally, I've always wondered, what do the other four columns do?
THE DOCTOR: Devine, I implore you not to do this. If you give Nazi Germany this technology...
STEPASHIN: Da, da. This is what I have been saying.
COSMO DEVINE: Well, you'll forgive me for being obvious, but that is rather the point, isn't it? They'll be unbeatable. Flying disc ships, death rays. I think they'll have the opposition beat.
THE DOCTOR: I can't let you do it.
COSMO DEVINE: Well, boo-hoo. Just how are you going to stop me?
STEPASHIN: What are you doing? You mustn't unseal the tank.
COSMO DEVINE: I'm afraid my pals in Berlin aren't worried about the spacemen, Prof. They just want the guns.
STEPASHIN: But it is priceless, priceless!
COSMO DEVINE: My heart bleeds. Okay, junk it, soldier.
THE DOCTOR: Oh dear.
STEPASHIN: I can't see anything. Do you think it is dead?
THE DOCTOR: No.
COSMO DEVINE: What are you waiting for, Fritzy? Christmas? Get the thing out of there and we'll split.
SOLDIER: Es ist schrecklich!
SOLDIER: [Translation - "it is horrible."]
COSMO DEVINE: Hey-ho. If you want something doing. Here, give me that gun.
COSMO DEVINE: What in God's...?
THE DOCTOR: How many creatures did you say were in the tank, Professor?
STEPASHIN: One. One only.
THE DOCTOR: Look.
STEPASHIN: Oh no.
THE DOCTOR: I think something else has been doing the splitting, Mr Devine. Binary fission. It's been reproducing.
STEPASHIN: There are?
THE DOCTOR: Yes. There must be thirty of them.
THE DOCTOR: End of part three on CD.
SOLDIER: Oh my God!
THE DOCTOR: Right, everybody out.
THE DOCTOR: Chaney, through the door, come on.
STEPASHIN: Okay. I made mistake. Now...
THE DOCTOR: We can't just leave them in there.
DON CHANEY: Watch me. Where's the Professor?
THE DOCTOR: Still inside, I'm afraid. You've got to get him out.
COSMO DEVINE: Your loyalty is touching, but a little misplaced. In case you haven't noticed, there's a bunch of giant fruitbats in there making short work of the Fuhrer's finest.
THE DOCTOR: We have to try.
COSMO DEVINE: You forget...
COSMO DEVINE: I still have this little baby.
THE DOCTOR: I'm going back for him.
DON CHANEY: Watch it.
THE DOCTOR: Professor.
COSMO DEVINE: Are you crazy?
STEPASHIN: Leave me.
DON CHANEY: Get a gun and shoot them, Prof. Come on!
STEPASHIN: I cannot. They are magnificent. Magnificent.
COSMO DEVINE: Enough! I won't warn you a second time.
THE DOCTOR: What now, Mr Devine? You've come away rather empty-handed, haven't you?
COSMO DEVINE: Shut up, I'm thinking.
COSMO DEVINE: Okay dokey, get moving, both of you.
DON CHANEY: What ... what are those things, Doctor?
THE DOCTOR: I haven't the foggiest. Mammalian, certainly, as our friend here put it so colourfully, they're like some form of giant bat. That sound.
DON CHANEY: But they're so ... savage. How could creatures like that...?
COSMO DEVINE: Yes, that had occurred to me too. They do act a little ... brusquely for supposedly intelligent creatures.
THE DOCTOR: Well, they're young, aren't they? You know what young carnivorous alien mammal-like monsters are like. Always getting into scrapes.
DON CHANEY: And you think someone's coming to find them?
THE DOCTOR: I do, and I have a nasty feeling that the grown-ups are even worse.

elements.text: PART FOUR
Opening Doctor Who theme tune, arranged by David Arnold.
Faint sounds of alien creatures screeching in the background.
What now, Mr Devine? You've come away rather empty-handed, haven't you?
Shut up, I'm thinking.
Muffled scream from beyond. Gun powered up.
Okay dokey, get moving, both of you.
Walking.
What ... what are those things, Doctor?
I haven't the foggiest. Mammalian, certainly, as our friend here put it so colourfully, they're like some form of giant bat. That sound.
But they're so savage. How could creatures like that...?
Yes, that had occurred to me too. They do act a little ... brusquely for supposedly intelligent creatures.
Well, they're young, aren't they? You know what young carnivorous alien mammal-like monsters are like. Always getting into scrapes.
And you think someone's coming to find them?
I do, and I have a nasty feeling that the grown-ups are even worse.
Crash.
Move.
Running off.
Space ship descends. Door opened, struggling to get free.
Let me go, you filthy great...
What an interesting structure.
Primitive.
But see how it spans the water, enabling craft to move across it. Ingenious.
Really? A race that has not even conquered basic gravitational forces is beneath our contempt.
What is this structure called, hairless things?
What?
It's a bridge.
Bridge? Yes. Well, this must be conserved for the records.
