Hah. It will make a glorious spectacle, as it crashes in flames, like the rest of this benighted globe.
Must we go through this every time?
Naturally.
Bleeps.
The breeding party is concealed close by. In fact, they are within the metal structure, the ... bridge.
Not for long. They shall be released from their bondage amongst these barbarians and set free. Free to destroy! Aah!
Well ... w-we'll discuss it later, all right? For now let's content ourselves with finding them.
Running. Screeching from the creatures in the background.
They're getting closer. Which way?
Er - down here.
Laser gun fired. Explosion.
What now?
Running forward.
Charley!
Doctor.
Thank heavens for that. Where did you get to?
Ellis? What the...?
Walking forwards.
Boss. Boss, are you okay?
Don't get too excited, we've brought some ... friends with us.
Ah. The grown-ups, I presume?
Walking in.
Good evening. My name is Cosmo Devine. I am in command here. If you want to see your lost property again you'll have to negotiate with me.
Kill it!
No, wait. This man is not in charge here. Erm, I am.
In the name of the joint Second Principle, I must destroy.
Gun powered up.
Destroy!
Naughty, naughty. I've got one of those too.
Gun powered up.
And you boys may be bigger than me, but I bet I could still make a whole mess of Jell-O out of those hairy old chests of yours.
What does it say? Destroy!
Streath, Streath, wait!
NORIAM clears his throat.
We have come to find ship. Erm ... star fall from sky full of treasure. We give some to you, if you help us find it.
Who do you think you're talking to? Pocahontas?
(laugh) I think they've got the measure of you , Devine.
Mm?
Streath, I think it would be wise if I interrogated these two hairless things alone. Why don't you take these others to one side, and, er, calm down.
(sigh.) Very well.
Moving off.
Doctor?
It's all right, Charley, I'll be with you in a moment.
Move!
Bustling others off.
So, you both lay claim to represent the creatures of this world. Who am I to believe?
Well, me. I'm the one with the gun.
Hmm. It is one of ours, is it not? You have rescued the breeding party?
He has, but only by force of arms. He has no authority to speak for the people of this planet.
And you do? What is this, Victorian revival week? Just who are you
anyway?
Door closed. Walking into room.
All right, Bix, I'm sorry, you can have my head on a goddamned plate if you...
Orson.
Oh my God. Shot?
Right in the middle of his...
I can see, Jack. Jesus, I Knew Biro had some shady friends, but this.
Background noise of screeching of creatures.
So where the hell have you been, Ellis? I mean, the whole place is crawling with Nazis and monsters. Where was my number two?
ELLIS about to speak but is reluctant to do so.
It was you, wasn't it? The one that was selling me out.
This isn't the time for recriminations.
Jeez ... I'm sorry, boss. I tried to make things right, but ... oh hell, they're here now.
And their little ones aren't far behind.
Be quiet, hairless things! I grow weary of this. You are not of significance. We must recover the defective hatchlings and then revert to the ... invasion plan.
Invasion plan?
Fluttering of bat-like wings.
Certainly. We are the Laiderplacker, conquerors of Space.
What, just the two of you?
Of course not. Our ship teems with life an, erm ... invincible invading army that will lay waste to this wretched planet.
You don't sound very convinced.
Ignore him. I want to help you.

No, I-let me see. Breeding party? That's what you said, wasn't it? A breeding party. Oh, I think I've got it. What do you do, you - you shoot off a ship full of eggs or something onto different planets, let them hatch...
Silence!
... cause chaos, scare the daylights out of the population and then you two turn up, and offer ... what?
Er...
NORIAM clears his throat.

Security. That's it, isn't it? It's a big bad universe out there. Is that what you're saying? You fool people into thinking they're vulnerable, and then ... It's a protection racket. A - an unbelievably huge protection racket. (Laughs.) Oh, that's good.
Is this true?
A herd brother crashed on this world with his hatchling. Obviously the breeding failed. We have come to recover them.
Briefly louder screeching in background.
They didn't fail. They were just a little late.
Then you can continue as normal. Subjugate this world. Don't listen to him. Even if you don't have an army, your weapons are far in advance of what we have here. You can still conquer.
Well, under normal circumstances, yes.
Explain?
Well, as you say, little planets like this, they're vulnerable, and I'm afraid someone else has beaten you to it.
What on Earth are you talking about?
What on Earth indeed. The fact is, my hairy friends, this planet has already been invaded.
What?
By Martians.
Mar ... tians?
Yes, Martians, from the planet Mars. Otherwise planet Sol Four, the red one you probably passed on your way in.
He's lying, don't listen to him.
Your words are false.
Are they? Would you believe that right now there's a squadron of Martian war machines marching across country to intercept you.
Do you play a game, thing?
No I do not. Your arrival here has not gone unnoticed. There are hostile invaders out to get you, bigger, nastier, hairier ones than you.
Did you not try to resist them?

Of course, but they're too strong. They're still arriving as we speak. Whole sections of the world are ignorant of their presence. Go now while you're still able. Let these people go. We'll gather up your chicks, and we can all go home.
No! This world is populated by trash and governed by weaklings. There are no invaders except yourselves. The Earth couldn't withstand any kind of properly-orchestrated assault.
Screeching.
Look out!
The hatchlings!
Stop them or I'll fire!
A restraining signal, Streath, quickly.
I warned you.
Laser gun blast.
Everybody out now, we can get round them.
Running.
Out of my way.
Stop...
Charley, come on.
Ellis!
Laser blast again.
No. You come here.
No good, boss. I can't...
A restraining sign... Oh don't bother, I'll do it myself.
Shrill noises, silence from the hatchlings.
There. That should keep them quiet for a while. Ah, the prisoners have escaped, Streath. Call yourself a destroyer?
There are still these hairless things.
Gun powered up.
I shall take great pleasure in destroying them. Aah!
Gentlemen, we need to talk. I want to make a deal.
Deal?
Yes.
Gun powered down.
Nov ... it - it seems to me you've been running a rather modest operation. I don't think you quite realise your own potential. Okay, so there's just two of you, but you could be big.
Gun powered off.
Big?

Yeah. Look, the fellas I was formally doing business with looked like a good investment. Perhaps you've heard of them - the Nazis, booming economy, expansionist plans, neat black uniforms, all that jazz? But you guys seem like a far better proposition. As I say, you may not be the biggest noise in the Universe, but ... in a little backwater like Earth - well, if you stick with me, you could be in the market for a take-over, a global take-over.
Walking over.
You scum, Devine.
That's my name.
You are proposing an alliance, Scum Devine?
No... No, I - I didn't ... Oh, never mind. An alliance? Well, let's call ita merger. I got the brains, you got the brawn. And I can tell you just where to hit this planet so it hurts most.
Aah! And why should we not destroy you, along with this entire world?
We can't destroy anything, Streath, and you know it. We ... haven't got the firepower.
You promised me one of these planets. I could destroy.
Listen. A few well-judged strikes in the right places, this world could be mine ... ah-ah-ah ... ours. There's so much to enjoy here, so much to exploit.
That is why we are here. Exploitation is the First Principle.
Then I guess we can do business together.
Very well, Scum Devine.
No, no...
We will consider your offer.
My name is...
We shall return the hatchlings to the ship, Scum Devine...
Stop calling me that!
Then what are we to call you?
Something appropriate for the soon-to-be master of the world. Alexander the Great, perhaps. What do you think Ellis, mm?
How about Judas?
That's a little rich coming from you.
Tell me, how does it feel to betray your entire planet?
A lot like betraying your country, but just that teensy bit more satisfying. Oh dear, Fatty, you are tiresome. I think my first act as emperor of the world will be...
Gun charged up.
...This.
Laser gun fired. ELLIS groans.
Why do you slay your own?
I'm a businessman. It was time to get rid of the dead wood.
See you ... in hell, Devine.
No doubt, but enjoy your head start.
Laser gun fired again. Sizzling. ELLIS groans. Burning.
As I say, trash, trash, trash.
Gun powered down.
Shall we go?
Metal door opened. Walking in.
That no-good lousy double-crossing fink! Why, I oughta...
Yes, well no doubt Mr Ellis is reflecting on the error of his ways right now.
Huh. I don't know who I'd rather be stuck with - those creatures or Cosmo Devine.
Now look, Chaney, I've got an idea. What's the main broadcasting network in these parts?
What, you mean like a ... like a radio?
Yes.
CBS, I guess. Why?
As I thought. Right. Now, you have contacts, yes? I mean, not all of your men were wiped out by Mr Devine's private army?
Hey, the Don's got men everywhere. This is my city.
I believe you, I believe you. Now, you're going to take us to CBS Studios and then I need you to mobilise some muscle, my friend. There's a blue box on the corner of ... Where was it, Charley?
Oh ... Broadway and...
Broadway and Thirty-Fourth Street. If you can arrange to have the box brought to the studios, and ... you do have a car?
Do I have a car? I got a Twenty-Nine Lamborghini. Used to belong to Capone.
Come on, then!
Running.
Look here.
Hmm?
It's that memo recorder Biro was so proud of.
Play switch pressed on tape.
(tape) I Knew I could rely on those rather dubious underworld contacts of yours. I'm sure no-one need hear of them now.
That's Cosmo Devine.
(tape) Devine, you'll let Jimmy go?
What the hell did he want with Bix Biro?
(tape) I only wish I could Mr Biro...
Dropped by for a donation?
(tape) ...but he met with an accident a short time ago.
(tape) Why, you...
(tape) Oh, there's just one more thing.
Three shots from a gun with a silencer.
(tape) That's Mr Devine to you.
Devine shot him!
JOHN HOUSEMAN sigh then turning off the tape.
Orson, this is turning into a very curious evening.
Walking in.
Mr Welles, the press boys are insisting on a statement. They've...
Cry by CARLA.
Okay Carla, i-it's okay.
Oh, Mr Biro, oh my God, what happened...?
Carla ... Carla, I want you to do something. I want you to go down to the lobby and fetch a policeman. Can you do that?
Oh my Lord...
Can you do that, Carla?
Yes, sir.
But Orson, are you sure? I mean, with the atmosphere down there...
Yes, you're right. Perhaps it would be better if cooler heads prevailed. All right Carla, could you get me a number? I need to speak to someone at the Central Intelligence Agency.
Yes, sir. Oh my...
Walking out. Door closes.
Okay Jack, let's play that tape again, from the beginning.
Button pressed. Tape rewinding.
Walking.
Look at this carnage. It's good, innit?
Well, the hatchlings certainly made short work of these hairless things. Are they all under control now?
Yes, and stored back on the ship. They will be unleashed again when the time comes to destroy...!
NORIAM clears his throat.
Er ... If the time comes to destroy this world.
Well then, I suggest we return to the ship to discuss this creature's idea of an alliance.
Are we finished here?
Most of the equipment is safely packed away, including the remains of the crashed ship. There's only the hatching tank left, and these few items.
Moving things.
Oh! What are these? The hairless things must have been tinkering with our glorious technology!
It may prove a useful study. I should like to conserve it all.
Oh! Where are we going to put it! It'll just end up gathering dust in the corner!
It is my duty as a Conserver.
Oh! Very well. I'll put it in with the prisoner. At least it won't be under my feet.
Carrying metal things away.
Inside a car. Car driving. Another car toots horn.
Ah, shut up!
Quite a turn of speed, this car of yours.
She's a beaut, ain't she, Doc? Not a scratch on her neither, except for the bullet holes in the door - some wise guy took a pop at Capone. Bam, bam, bam, bam!
Screeching.
Eyes on the road, please.
Yeah. So what's the plan, Doc? I still got a rendezvous arranged with the
boys. You know, they could get the troops in, and...
Oh, no, no, no, no, I told you. This technology's too dangerous for anyone to get hold of, even the, er ... the good guys.
Okay. So I get the blue box to CBS, then what?
Then we shall see.
Doctor, if there's just two of these aliens, then why are we getting so excited?
Because despite Mr Devine's bluster, he was right. With an insider like him on their side, they can still cause unprecedented damage to this world.
You have a plan?
Of course. Tell me, Charley, are you fond of drama?

Serious? Of course I'm serious. Look, could I speak to someone in authority? ... You are someone in authority? Well, you've got a mighty strange way of showing it ... My name? Yes, Welles. Orson Welles. No, I'm not joking. What? What did you say?
Click of disconnection. Phone chime as receiver replaced.
Don't tell me, they didn't believe you.
Well, apparently they don't believe I'm Orson Welles, and if they did they would come round here and kick my butt for what we've just done.
Louder noises of traffic chaos as though a window is opened.
Look at them down there. If we show our faces they'll tear us apart.
Quieter noise as window closed.
Oh, this is a mess.
Door opens. Walking in.
My thoughts exactly.
What the devil...?
Oh, it is you, isn't it?
Who?
Who the hell are you?
You're Orson Welles, as I live and breathe. I'm such a fan. I've seen all your films.
But I haven't made any.
Of course not, but you will, you will.
Doctor.
Mm?
Look.
Walking over.
Oh dear. Poor fellow. Shot?
Yes.
Who was he?
Bix Biro.
His pen name?
I beg your pardon?
You must be...
John Houseman, sir. You are...?
A pleasure. I'm the Doctor. This is Charley.
DON CHANEY walking in, out of breath.
Okay, the blue box is on its way, Doc.
Now what?
And this is Mr Chaney.
Chaney?
Don Chaney?
Yeah. What's it to youse?
You, er, you have this spaceship?
Excellent. I don't have to bring you up to speed. Now, you've been working tonight, haven't you?
Yes.
It's just as I thought! I knew I'd remembered correctly. The War of the Worlds, yes? You've panicked half the city into believing there's an alien invasion underway.
So it would seem.
Well, there is.
Are you a reporter?
Gentlemen, I need your help. This planet is in grave danger. An extraterrestrial force has landed, and it'll probably be quite a job to get shot of them.
Are you serious?
What do you want us to do?
Can you get your actors back together again?
What's all this in aid of?
I'll explain later. Can you get them?
I doubt if anybody could get through the mob outside.
We did.
But the police...
Yeah, the cops and me have a ... an understanding.
How reassuring.
On second thoughts, we don't have time. We'll have to do some doubling up.
Care to enlighten us, Doctor?
Once the TARDIS is here, all will become clear. Now, let's get to the studio.
Whatever you say.
Cheer up, Orson. The play's the thing, in which thou we'll the conscience of the King.
Er, er, how's that?
Hamlet.
You've lost me there, Doctor, whoever you are.
But sure...? Oh, never mind. Now, we'll need scripts.
Pacing and occasional tapping on window.
This is outrageous! Keeping me in here like an animal. Oh, why I had to give up my weapon so easily. It was a gesture of good faith, you baboons! Oh well, I guess that's where good faith gets you.
Rustling of pages of a script.
All right, everyone, are we all clear?
I think so, Doctor.
Remember, nothing must break the frame. Keep up the illusion as long as you can.
We can't broadcast this again, they'll crucify us.
Don't worry, this particular production is going out on a very special frequency, and to a very select audience. Orson?
Okay, Mr Chaney, Jack, Charley. Shall we start with the weather forecast?
Just like before?
Just like before. Go ahead.
JOHN HOUSEMAN clears his throat.
You're on!
Maximum temperature sixty-six, minimum forty-eight. This weather report comes to you from the Government Weather Bureau. We now take you to the...
(whispering) Now what?
(whispering) I go into the TARDIS.
Walking off, opening door, and door closing over while John Houseman speaks.
...Meridian room in the Hotel Park Plaza in downtown New York, where you will be entertained by the music of Ramon Raquello and his orchestra.
Music playing. TARDIS control room noises.
Now, a little tweaking. Where are you, where are you...?
(speaker) Er ... Ladies and gentlemen...
Now, what sort of frequency would hit the spot?
(speaker) ... to bring you a special bulletin...
This one?
Noise from console.
(speaker) ... from the intercontinental radio news...
No, no. How about...
Loud erratic noise.
Definitely not. Ah, maybe...
Gentle humming.
(speaker) ... Observatory, Chicago, Illinois. Reports observing several explosions of incandescent gas...
I thought we had a deal. Sticking me in here with all this...
Thump on metal.
... junk!
Tapping.
What?
More metallic tapping.
Hello? Is somebody ... in here with me?
Door opened.
Come then, hairless thing. Destroyer Streath is most anxious to know the weak points in your world's defences.
(sigh.) And I can't wait to show him.
Well, what is it?
Nothing. I - I thought I heard something.
There is only the hatching tank and this ... detritus.
Yes, yes, of course. Let's get out.
Walking out. Noise of door closing.
(speaker) As I was saying, I was listening to the radio kinda halfways.
(speaker) Yes Mr Wilmont, and then you saw something?
(speaker) Not first off...
That's it, Orson. Keep going.
At present, the main powers would be this country, the Soviet Union, France, England and the Germans. A systematic attack on those countries would in my opinion, leave the rest floundering.
(speaker) And what did you hear?
(speaker) A hissing sound. Er, like this...
What is that?
We've been picking it up for some time. It appears to be the hairless things communicating.
It's just radio.
This is happening now.
I guess. Don't worry about it.
(speaker) ... something smacked to the ground, knocked me clear out of my chair.
(speaker) Well, were you frightened, Mr Wilmont?
(speaker) I turned by head out the window...
They appear to be reporting our arrival.
Hah! Much good will it do them.
Listen, you can forget all this stuff about protection rackets - chicken-feed. One concentrated strike could completely disorientate them. The whole world's in a war fever anyway.
How do we know it's working?
Shh.

Good heavens, something's wriggling out of the shadows like a grey snake. Now it's another one and another one and another one. They look like tentacles to me ... There, I can see the thing's body, it's large, large as a bear and it glistens like wet leather.
ORSON WELLES still talking on radio in background.
And once morale starts to crumble...
And tell me, what is your price for all this?
Oh, I don't want much. Dominion over America, or some such.
Noriam! Listen!
Streath! I am conducting...
Listen!
(speaker) ... face or monster or whatever it is...
This is not a report of our landing.
(speaker) Possibly gravity or something, the things rising up, the crowd falls back down...
This planet is under attack.
No, no, no, it's a drama, a play. They were broadcasting it earlier.
(speaker) I'll have to stop the description until I take a new position...
Creatures from Mars. I have heard of them. A feared race of Warriors. You have tricked us, hairless thing.
No!
(speaker) A humped shape is rising out of the pit, I can make out a tall beam of light against...
The other hairless thing spoke the truth. You hoped to distract us, while your true allies launched their strike against the Earth.
What the hell are you talking about?
Humming.
Engines are initiated, Streath. I suggest we continue this conversation in orbit.
Agreed.
(speaker) ... spreading everywhere, it's coming this way. About twenty yards to my right...
(speaker) Ladies and gentlemen, due to circumstances beyond our control we are unable to continue the broadcast from Grover's Mill.
Your death will be extremely prolonged, hairless thing. You have deceived us, and must pay the price.
What?
I must say, I agree. In this case, destruction is necessary, and a long drawn-out nasty destruction at that.
No, it isn't real, I swear it!
Take him back to the cell.
Aah!
Charley, pop into the TARDIS, would you, keep an eye on their position.
Are you off somewhere?
No, I want to go.
Walking, door opened/closed.

People of the Earth, your attention. Your planet is now under Martian control. Surrender is not an option. We intend to, er ... devastate your planet until it hangs like a cinder in Space. All life will be extinguished. We shall ... drain your rivers, er, level your mountains, annihilate your infestation from this world.
Whispered
How am I doing?
Very good.
Door opened.
I think they're on the move.
It worked.
Looks like it.
Well Jack, it looks like we fooled 'em.
That's twice in one night.
That false creature. We have saved our skins by...
Look at them go...
Listen!
(speaker) Half-way gone with whatever passes for a tail between their legs.
(speaker) It was quite a gamble Doctor.
(speaker) Oh yes, but broadcasting on their own high frequency must have helped. It certainly rammed home the message ... What's that red light for?
(speaker) Oh God, we're still on the air.
Static.
No! The Scum Devine spoke the truth. It was a trick!
Flapping of wings.
Aah! Return! Destroy, destroy, destroy!
The signal's increasing, they're coming back.
Taps on metal.
Listen to me, he tricked you. Let me out of here.
More taps on metal. Then a metallic noise as a door opens.
What the hell? Professor?
Walking out.
Thank heavens.
He groans.
It is you. Good, that is good. I was hoping to see you again.
But you ... I mean, those things.
Oh, those wonderful creatures. Wonderful, but deadly. I managed to crawl into the tank. It saved my life.
You're bleeding.
Da. I am not long for this world.
Yeah, well, I ... Look, I haven't got time for this. What have you got there?
This? This is a puzzle, Mr Devine. A question to which I hope soon to provide an answer, very soon.
Some sort of a machine. Is it theirs? The aliens, I mean?

No. It is mine. Constructed with a little help from their technology. I saved it from destruction, and here. Ah! Here is all that I need. They have brought all my experiments with them. Ah, they are wonderful creatures but not, I think, terribly bright.
What are you doing? Listen, I got to get out of here. These creatures are my ticket to the high life.
No, Mr Devine, I think not. Now, the answer to my question.
Question? What question?
Have you not guessed? (Laugh.) Saving the Earth is not a bad thing to die for, eh?
What the hell are you talking about?
The question is, am I, Yuri Stepashin, the first man to build a working atomic bomb?
Ticking.
We will destroy all of it. Al! Every last atom.
Except for the parts we conserve.

Oh, shut up. you old fool! This is a time for action. I, Destroyer Streath, will plunge this Earth into a pit of flame, I shall watch its death-throes as I tear it apart stone by stone, boil away its waters, purge its devious hairless things in the pure flame of my unquenchable vengeance!
Ticking.
Er ... what's that ticking?
Blast of atomic energy.

(radio) ... Which lit up the skies last night had nothing to do with the Mercury Theatre radio broadcast which caused panic over a wide area of the State. Astronomers say it is most likely another fragment of the meteorite which struck our atmosphere just over a month ago.
Radio turned off.
Well, they obviously didn't get far. I wonder why. Still, rather neat, wasn't it?
Oh, there's a lot to be sorted out. Biro's death for one thing.
Er, no, Jack, I got a call from the CIA, they ... have ways of covering up things like this. Actually they said they were expecting to hear from you, Mr Chaney.
Yeah well, er, that all counts for squat now. No merchandise, no nothin’.
Thankfully.
But people must have seen things. I mean, spaceships over New Jersey?
Mass hysteria, Charley, and thanks to Orson and his friends the CIA already have their cover story.
Which reminds me. Time to face the music.
The Press are outside?
Uh-huh.
Oh no. How do I look?
You look like someone who's just about to become the most famous man in America.
You think so? Say...
Come along, Orson.
Walking off.
What do you think, Jack? Abjectly apologetic, or humble but proud?
Don't let them cut Ambersons! Oh no, I mustn't interfere.
Walking over.
Hey, Doctor. You're a resourceful guy. You want a job with prospects?
Already got one, thank you. And if I were you, Mr Chaney, I'd find myself a quieter occupation.
(chuckle.) Unlike us, I daresay. Hey, aren't we due in Singapore?
Yes, and we're eight years late. Best be off. Goodbye, Mr Chaney.
Walking off.
But where are you...
Door opened.
Bye.
Hey, what is this?
Door closed. TARDIS dematerialisation.
Well, I'll be a...
He laughs.
Trick or treat.
Closing 1930s music.
Closing Doctor Who theme tune, arranged by David Arnold.

parts.searchable_dialogue:
THE DOCTOR: What now, Mr Devine? You've come away rather empty-handed, haven't you?
COSMO DEVINE: Shut up, I'm thinking.
COSMO DEVINE: Okay dokey, get moving, both of you.
DON CHANEY: What ... what are those things, Doctor?
THE DOCTOR: I haven't the foggiest. Mammalian, certainly, as our friend here put it so colourfully, they're like some form of giant bat. That sound.
DON CHANEY: But they're so savage. How could creatures like that...?
COSMO DEVINE: Yes, that had occurred to me too. They do act a little ... brusquely for supposedly intelligent creatures.
THE DOCTOR: Well, they're young, aren't they? You know what young carnivorous alien mammal-like monsters are like. Always getting into scrapes.
DON CHANEY: And you think someone's coming to find them?
THE DOCTOR: I do, and I have a nasty feeling that the grown-ups are even worse.
COSMO DEVINE: Move.
CHARLEY POLLARD: Let me go, you filthy great...
NORIAM: What an interesting structure.
STREATH: Primitive.
NORIAM: But see how it spans the water, enabling craft to move across it. Ingenious.
STREATH: Really? A race that has not even conquered basic gravitational forces is beneath our contempt.
NORIAM: What is this structure called, hairless things?
ELLIS: What?
